ReviewText: This is a huge museum with a vast collection. I liked how they integrated paintings with period pieces. Highly recommend!

My parents first took me here when I was a little boy. I'm now 70. Having traveled to almost every state in the USA, the Caribbean, and most of Western Europe...by now, I've been to countless museums. I believe the greatest are in New York. But in my opinion, this is one of the best outside of NYC. It is beautiful inside and out. It is inspired by the ancient Romans and Greeks. The museum is extremely large, with seemingly endless interior spaces. The permanent collections are almost incomparable. And when they have a special exhibit, it's always thorough and impressive. My only complaint is that in recent years, it's become too expensive.

The watercolor exhibit was a gem. Unexpected and profound it was curated perfectly allowing a salon experience. The permanent collection was well laid out and easy to navigate with the information on the works succinct and informative. The staff were very friendly and helpful. The Burrito Bar was a good place for lunch and the gift shops were varied and easy to get in and out of. I will go back.

Once you figure out how to park or take public transport, the museum is on of the BEST art museums in the United States. Relatively inexpensive to enter. Start on a floor with an interest to you AND leave PLENTY of time. First visit? Plan on at least 2 days, full days to visit. The pass is good for 2 consecutive days. You can leave the museum and go out for lunch and come back. The displays are grand.

The museum sports a statue of "Rocky" on the grounds, a major photo op. Inside I gravitated toward the impressionists paintings and they were wonderful. There is also a restaurant in the museum that's quite good. The gift shop had some nice things as well.
Very large facility with a lot of art. Van Gogh, Monet and Eakins were my favorite. The pass is good for two days and a total of three museums.
2 of my 4 days in the city were spent at this lovely museum. I am from Washington, D.C. where we have the great Smithsonian museums. I was so happy to find this must-see gem.

I have been to this museum many times as I went to high school in the area. It is one of the most beautiful sites in Philadelphia. I could never advise anyone to come to this city without visiting here. It is completely intoxicating so much so that you will never forget it.
This is a world class museum. The Mexican Revolution exhibit was impressively thorough. I Recommend the museum to visitors of all ages and the gardens behind the museum are breathtaking in Spring.
ReviewTitle: Mexican Revolution exhibit was huge and fantastic

ReviewText: a bit light on contemporary art but still good. Viewed most of the 2 floors in 3 hours. A bit heavy on religious art for my tast. But, that is just my personal preference.

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: Having visited the Rodin in Paris, I wasn't exactly sure what to expect. I can honestly say I was not disappointed. While it is small in comparison, it is beautifully designed. The entrance and gardens are lovely - even in winter - and provide a beautiful setting for the museum and art pieces outside. The Thinker, the Gates of Hell and the Kiss are all reproduced beautifully. The inside is delicate and beautiful - with soaring ceilings and late windows. And interesting feature is a small study room. We took a few minutes to sit and rest and really enjoyed thumbing through the many books describing the life of Rodin. Really charming was a children's book on the artist. This is a small museum and you won't need much time. But it will be even more beautiful when the garden is in bloom. I would definitely return in nicer weather.

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: The building and grounds are beautiful and some of his best works are on display outside. Inside it just gets better. A well curated collection and free with your ticket to the Philadelphia Art Museum, it is well worth the time and short walk. The tours are informative and free.
ReviewTitle: Rivals his home museum in Paris

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: Entrance passes at the Phil Museum of Art are accepted here also. If you enjoy sculpture and Rodin, this is the ONLY place to go! These are NOT replicas. They are the real thing. Some from the first makings to the final work. One can get close to the works; take pictures (FLASH OKAY)!

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: This is a small museum with a small number of pieces, The Thinker, The Gates of Hell, the Three Shades, The Cathedral... your ticket to the Museum of Art will get you into the Rodin and it's right next door. Don't miss it.
ReviewTitle: A taste of Paris... the wonderful Rodin....

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: We stopped here on a historical tour of Philly. It was small but excellent. You can view it all in less than 30mins. Some amazing Rodin pieces, especially on the grounds. Highly recommend you visit.
ReviewTitle: Small but worth a quick visit

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: I have visited multiple times when in the Philadelphia area. If you like fine art you must visit. My wife and I enjoyed it so much on our first visit I found myself going back on subsequent visits to Philadelphia. This is a MUST SEE if you are in the Philadelphia area

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: The Philly Rodin Museum contains some interesting works, but it small compared to the Rodin Museum in Paris. But, if you cannot get to Paris, the Philly Rodin Museum gives you a flavor of Rodin's works. Plus, it is located in the same general area as the Barnes Foundation and the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Admissions is included in the Philly Pass.

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: This is a great little museum where you can view Rodin's work (many were copies) up close. Photography is allowed. The gardens are beautiful. Wish I had the time but would be a great combo to do with Barnes Collection.
ReviewTitle: Great collection in a beautiful space

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: The Rodin Museum only being a few minutes away from the Museum of Art was a nice little addition to my activities in Philadelphia, it also gave me the opportunity to see and learn some more about the artist than what I already knew (very little really), as yet having failed to make it to the Rodin Museum in Paris it seemed like the best compromise. Outside is a lovely garden area with several pieces and along with a copy of the ‘Gates of Hell’, the museum inside is more compact, along the lines size of an exhibit room at the Museum of Art, but in the small area is an impressive collection of Rodin pieces, not just the finished pieces but the casts and work in progress too. The great information provided along with what I saw made it incredibly enlightening for me and I’m really glad I took the opportunity to visit. Entry would only have been $10, but since I’d visited The Philadelphia Museum of Art earlier was included with my $20 admission from there (another incentive to visit).
ReviewTitle: A chance to see and learn more about an artist I knew very little about

ProviderLocation: Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street , Philadelphia , PA 19101
ReviewText: This museum had quite a few interesting sculptures especially the Gates of Hell from Dante's Inferno. I enjoyed the stories about the people who were actually sculpted - most were so vain and new to this type of art that they didn't like the way they were depicted or cast in stone. Little did they know how famous these statues would be now especially in Paris. As for the courtyard, I absolutely loved it! You can definitely get lost in a book or even just in thought sitting outside on the bench overlooking the fountain. This museum was free will donation if I remember correctly and can be seen in a reasonable amount of time. I will more than likely return in the winter to see the courtyard with snow. I am sure it will be very beautiful.

The first time we visited the Barnes Foundation, several years ago in the original location, we were a bit disappointed. I know, most people would never say that. But the building was in decay and we really couldn't appreciate the collection. This time, in the new, modern museum allowed us to see the art in an entirely new light. First, the building is gorgeous, the rooms are very comfortable to walk around in and the natural light coming through adds to the ambience. Visitors should know they can download an app on their phones where they can listen to a docent explaining the paintings and other art pieces. Visitors should also know that the only restrooms are outside and downstairs from the main galleries. You have to let the staff know as you leave that you are coming back and you have, basically 15 minutes to do so. Otherwise, you'll be standing in line again until there is room inside the main rooms for more people. Don't miss the second floor. The African art is spectacular!
ReviewTitle: Beautiful and Much Improved from the Original Building

ReviewText: The museum is a tribute to its founder who had strong opinions on the appreciation of art. Due to the opinions of its founder, the museum is unique in its displays of the collection. We took a private docent tour, which I highly recommend.

My boyfriend had visited the Barnes when it was outside of town and he was impressed with how accurately the rooms were reproduced in the new location. I was impressed with with the extensive and beautiful collection. My only regret is that we didn't have enough time to see both floors. We spent the morning viewing all the first floor rooms. And needing a mental break we left to have delicious pizza at the Pizzeria Vetri nearby. The collection of art is extensive and beautiful. Lots of Cezanne, Matisse and Monet. The idea of an ensemble is unique to this museum and made it enjoyable and possible to view so many works of art. I've even been inspired to create my own ensembles in decorating my apartment. I dare to say that we enjoyed visiting this museum more than Philadelphia Museum of Art. A must do in Philadelphia. Next time we'll visit the second floor !!!

It is worth it make a special trip to Philadelphia just to see this collection of artwork that cannot be seen anywhere else. It is extensive and breathtaking. The docent we had was excellent, making the tour interactive. The tour was intimate. There aren't throngs of people about. You can be in a room by yourself with Renoir, Matisse, Picasso masterpieces. This museum/foundation is beyond compare. If you love art, make your reservation now. You won't be disappointed.

Mr. Barnes was eccentric. He collected art. He arranged it as he liked it and that is the way it has stayed. He acquired Picasso blue period pieces, Bosch, Cezanne, Renoir Demuth and Van Goh you can't see anywhere else. It is a collection of rare and wondrous pieces displayed in a seemingly random fashion that will require more time to appreciate but worth the effort. They also have a superb restaurant. The staff and docents were very friendly and helpful. Try to avoid peak times as some of the galleries are not as large as you would expect for so much art in one place, but it is a must see and they have other spaces for current exhibits that were also worth the trip. Go, linger and get immersed in the collection that Mr. Barnes lived with and for.

After having enjoyed the splendors of the Barnes Foundation’s I wandered over to Room12 on the ground floor to take a look at 3 small paintings by the African-American painter Horace Pippin that Dr. Barnes had acquired in the 1940s. They are no.18, ‘Abraham Lincoln and his Father Building their Cabin on Pigeon Creek’ (1934); no. 22 ‘Christ and the Woman of Samaria’ (1940); and no. 24 ‘Supper Time’ (1940). Who was Horace Pippin to elicit such interest from Dr. Barnes? Dr. Barnes had a long-standing interest in African and African-American art. He met Pippin, a self-taught, modest man through the Philadelphia art dealer Robert Carlen who also had dealings with Dr. Barnes. Pippin had been in the French trenches during WWI and, after a disabling injury to his shoulder, returned to Pennsylvania. His illustrated war diaries became an early inspiration for his art and to help with his post-war ”blues.” Holding his disabled arm with his left hand, and working painstakingly slowly, he finished his first oil painting, ‘The End of War: Starting Home’, in 1929. Robert Carlen later donated it to the Philadelphia Museum of Art. In 1940 Carlen mounted Pippin’s first exhibition in his Philadelphia gallery, and Dr. Barnes wrote the introduction to the catalogue, as he also did for Pippin’s second show in 1942. Dr. Barnes who had earlier acquired ‘Abraham Lincoln etc.’ now also purchased ‘Supper Time’ and ‘Christ and the Woman of Samaria.’ Dr. Barnes called Pippin an American original in whose paintings the rhythms of African-American spirituals resonated. But the relationship between Pippin and Dr. Barnes soon took a downturn. As Pippin became better known and the prices for his paintings escalated, Dr. Barnes insisted on the price paid for earlier paintings. Pippin’s dealer did not agree. Enjoy the Pippin paintings in Room 12 and this story within the story.
ReviewTitle: Dr. Barnes and African-American painter Horace Pippin

ReviewText: The house collection at the Barnes is lovely. Some beautiful pieces for sure. Overall, the design of the museum is lackluster surrounding the primary collection - nothing special. The staff is much more enamored with their own virtue than is warranted, but say la vie. The special exhibition space was not at all well done for the most recent Masterworks of French Photography, 1890-1950 exhibit. Poorly done actually.

The Barnes has all the best art. Go there and decide if you're more of a Cezanne fan or Renoir is more your speed. They got some deep Picassos and Van Goghs and Manets and Matisses. They also have special exhibits showcasing all different pieces. Sometimes there's live music or dance in the central chamber. Overall the best choice. And the free library is pretty cool too

I ran over here on Sunday morning for a two hour visit before the crowds. First overall impression, it reminded me of a small Prado. The Impressionist art is arranged in rows of three in smallish rooms. Cards are available for identification of all art. It took a few minutes, but I got used to it, except the lighting was such that the top row of art was often too far away and reflected light too easily. Still, the Renoirs, Cezannes, Sisleys, Gaugins, Rousseaus, Van Goghs, Monets, Manets etc were absolutely incredible both in the mammoth collection and in the art itself. I probably could have done without all the featured hardware mixed between the art, but after awhile I learned to deal with this arrangement.
ReviewTitle: The Arrangement of Art is a Little Strange, but an Overall WOW!

ReviewText: Long fascinated by the story behind the Barnes collection, I was disappointed I had never managed to visit the Merion location. On a recent trip to Philadelphia, I put visiting The Barnes Foundation at the top of my to-do list. I have no argument with the decision to move the collection and in general I liked the new building. But I did not experience the joy I almost always feel in museums, large or small, when I am surrounded by great works of art. Part of that was due to the fact that so many of the pieces need cleaning. That was depressing. There were individual pieces that I loved, and one certainly has a chance to study certain artists, particularly Cezanne, Renoir and Matisse, in some depth. For me it was particularly interesting to see how Renoir created many variations on the same idea and how some works were so intriguing while others were immediately forgettable. But the experience of moving from room to room was almost like being in an "art for sale" warehouse. Adding to this feeling was the fact that many of those around me were moving through the museum like they were part of a tour group on a tight schedule, determined to lay eyes on everything but really see nothing. Perhaps the sheer volume of the collection makes this happen as one Renoir after another after another after another induces a sort of trance. I have never had this feeling before in an art museum. As I am a frequent visitor to the Gardner Museum in Boston, I am sympathetic to museums that display their collections as their founders intended and have multiple pieces displayed in close proximity and oddly configured. It works at the Gardner but doesn't at the Barnes. Other reviewers have advised reading up on the history of the Barnes collection and the artists it highlights. I think that is very wise advice for this particular museum. I am glad I saw the collection which is, indeed, amazing. I am just sorry that the overall experience was so dispiriting.
a museum of medical history that includes a rotating exhibit (medicine in the Civil War at the moment) and much history of medical practice along with a collection of medical oddities.

Walking distance from center city. Was on our bucket list of Philly museums. High ticket price of $ 18.00. Great for medical people, not for squeamish. Sat.visit, too crowded, could not get to all exhibits. All items are well maintained, behind glass, No modern exhibition methods. Maybe 1 to 1.5 hours visit. Very unique.

This museum is small but we spent about 3 hours here as there was much to read and see, they cram a lot of stuff in here. It is weird medical curiosities and some of it can be a bit morbid, we love that kind of stuff so we had a great time. It is also educational. When we visited last there was a traveling exhibit of microscopic photos of diseases. I particularly enjoyed Grover Cleveland's tumor, the wall of skulls, and the "soap lady". In the gift shop I bought a Siamese twins gingerbread cookie cutter, it's fabulous!

The musuem was unique and worth the visit. I thought it would have been a touch bigger. We went on a sunday at 330 and the place was extremely busy. People pushing their way through to look at something you are trying to see. If I were to go again it would definitely be during the week.

I heard many people complaining how "Small" the museum is. It is plenty big enough in my opinion as most of the objects are small and dont need much room. You could spend alot of time hear just observing the pieces and pondering how they came to be here and how things like these can exist. Very interesting Displays.

The Mutter Museum is all about anatomical oddities. A medical museum it's filled with an amazing collection of skulls, variations on deformed bones, and medical maladies across the ages. Where else can you go to see the world's largest ovarian cyst? Or every variation of cancer and it's impact on the skeleton. Not for the faint of heart but very cool if you are scientifically curious. The outdoor medical garden is also worth a stroll! Can get a bit crowded with school groups but worth the effort.

Even with a medical background, I struggled with this museum. There are many interesting aspects, but others are quite disturbing. There is a lot to learn here, but you better not have a weak stomach!
ReviewTitle: Not for the faint of heart

ReviewText: An excellent collection of medical anomalies and historical items. A strong stomach is apparently necessary, as there were reports of someone losing their cookies the previous day! Must take time to read the placards to truly understand the purpose of each specimen, it took about 2 hours to see it all. The downstairs sector housed the most diverse and interesting specimens.

What do a part of Albert Einstein’s brain, the plaster death cast of the torso of once famous Siamese twins and 139 skulls displayed for anatomic purposes have in common? I wanted to find out and went on a self-guided tour at the Mutter Museum of the College of Physicians of Philadelphia at 19 S 22nd Street. I found that my knowledge of anatomic and pathological materials is woefully inadequate, at times even scary. However, I was comforted to learn that many of the over 2,000 specimens displayed here served Professor Mutter and his colleagues at the College of Physicians as teaching tools and for the benefit of medical advancement. I walked away pondering that each skull and anatomical oddity had once belonged to a living human being and, given a chance, would probably be eager to tell his or her life’s story before becoming a medical specimen. Don’t miss the exhibit “Our finest clothing - A layered history of our skin” on the upper floor. You will probably think twice now before hours of careless sunbathing next summer. Enjoy and learn. Except on selected public holidays, the Mutter Museum is open every day from 10 to 5.
There are unique things in this museum. I would not say this is a top priority for tourist coming to Philadelphia. If you are into medical history this is a cool thing to see.
ReviewTitle: Local history but a little dry

ReviewText: The purpose of our visit in December 2016 was to see the Bill Graham Rock & Roll Revolution Exhibit, which was really fun. This was our first visit to the museum. We had been told it was a beautiful museum but we were not prepared for how modern and light it was. The floor plan is fairly open which gives you a lot of room to appreciate the exhibits. Those who visit will learn about the Jewish experience in the US, starting with the first immigrants in the 1600s all the way to present day. The gift shop was also very good.

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106
ReviewText: This is a must see for everyone. The history of the Jewish culture and its influence on all of us should not be missed. While some of the exhibits were reminders of our less than noble moments, there was much to be proud of in the assimilation and welcoming of this once feared group of immigrants. The four floors of exhibits take you from colonial America to present day in a thoughtful and insightful view of the value of the Jewish culture and the benefits of inclusion instead of fear.

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106

ReviewTitle: Cool, but a little boring if you aren't Jewish

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106
ReviewText: Arranged in chronological order, it's an easy museum to visit with lots to read and plenty for kids as well. Plan on 2-4 hours.
ReviewTitle: Well arranged and informative. Excellent shop for Jewish gifts.

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106
ReviewText: This is one of the better of the Jewish museums that we've been to. The Bill Graham was not quite as good as the one in San Francisco, but fun in spite of that. The other sections of the museum were both informative and fun. Lots of Jewish American history, and very well done.

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106
ReviewText: I visited the National Museum of American Jewish History in February 2017. It was free. You must pass through security and a metal detector. I recommend focusing on the 3rd and 2nd floors. Take the elevator up to the 3rd floor where the history of immigration of Jews from Europe in the late 1800's through to 1945 and the end of World War 2 is covered. My grandfather immigrated to the United States from Russia and entered the USA at Philadelphia and not Ellis Island. The museum was able to explain to me that these immigrants were brought into the port of Philadelphia and booked and processed on Washington Street. The 2nd floor covers 1945 to present with a heavy emphasis on Israel. Of interest is the vote of the United Nations to approve Israel as a country. If you focus on these two floors you can visit the museum in less than an hour.

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106
ReviewText: I visited the NMAJH on a sunny holiday in February with, as it turned out, an avalanche of mostly Jewish families with children. Time for the youngsters to learn and the older generation to remember. Located on Independence Mall across the street from the National Constitution Center and a short walk away from Independence Hall one is instantly reminded that Jewish participation in the life of the United States of America is far reaching and deep. It is best to begin one’s exploration with Foundations of Freedom (1654-1880) on the fourth floor. This was a time of expansion and growth on the American continent and thus a natural destination for those trying to escape from social, including religious, political and economic turmoil on the European and especially the central European continent. It is appropriate to remember that the Liberty Bell, the symbol of American independence and freedom, traveled to America from its English foundry on the ship of the Jewish merchant Nathan Levy. Dreams of Freedom (1880-1945) on the 3rd floor documents the attempts of immigrants, Jewish or otherwise, to preserve their heritage and traditions while trying to integrate themselves into their new world. Choices and Challenges of Freedom (1945-Today) on the 2nd floor includes the post-WWII fight for civil rights, women’s equality and support for the new State of Israel. “Only in America” is the topic of the changing video panorama on the main floor where you make the acquaintance of such distinguished Jewish-American personalities as Jonas Salk (the end of polio), Justice Brandeis after whom a distinguished university is named, Golda Meir (Prime Minister of Israel), Betty Friedan, Jerome Robbins, Saul Bellow, Estee Lauder and many, many others who have made substantial contributions to American public life. And yes, as the banners outside the museum proclaim, you will also see the first movie camera of the film genius Steven Spielberg, Irving Berlin’s piano and Albert Einstein’s pipe. The National Museum of American Jewish History was founded in 1904, and the streamlined glass and terra cotta building opened in 2010. The Museum is affiliated with the Smithsonian Institution and is open to the public during regular hours from Tuesday-Sunday.
ReviewTitle: 20,000 objects to tell Jewish history in America.

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106
ReviewText: It's a good museum for people who want to learn the Jewish history. As a person who had limited knowledge about Jewish history, I enjoyed the visit here and feel I have learned a lot from the visit.
ReviewTitle: Good place to learn Jewish history

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106
ReviewText: The museum is a gem. It covers in an in depth and quality manner a gigantic mass of information. But they do it in a way that doesn't make it seem so daunting. The displays are presented in a manner that is appropriate for younger children, yet also providing more than sufficient information to hold an adult's attention. When I visited that also had a temporary display covering the life of Bill Graham which wonderfully gave me an understanding of his works and why he was an important actor in the music scene.

ProviderName: National Museum of American Jewish History
ProviderLocation: 101 South Independence Mall East , Philadelphia , PA 19106
ReviewText: I went to see the Bill Graham exhibit. Go see it if you love rock and roll! Well done exhibit and I learned a lot. Beautiful period poster for various acts from the 1960's what a trip!
ReviewTitle: wonderful venue and free docent tour

ReviewText: At only $5, this is a great value and worthy of an hour or two long visit. We left with a greater understanding of the man and his contributions.
ReviewTitle: Great for a quick visit to get to know Benjamin Franklin's life

ReviewText: As a connoisseur of museums I was extremely impressed with this little gem. It contains an excellently designed set of exhibits that focus well on a few aspects that cove Ben Franklin's life without overwhelming you. It has a lot of interactive elements that worked well and weren't broken like they are in so many museums. It is located and the site of the Franklins' house in Philadelphia so that is very cool. The only part I didn't particularly like was the animation style on the short videos in the exhibits, but other than that it is great. Being underground also means that it is a great way to escape the heat.
ReviewTitle: One of the Best Designed Museums

ReviewText: Maybe my expectations were too high knowing that we are talking about Ben Franklin here, but I was underwhelmed with a little simplistic approach of this place. I am under the impression that it targets more kids than adults, and there is nothing wrong with that, but there are too many exhibits looking more like cartoons. I would definitely go there with kids and introduce them to the genius comparable with only Leonardo da Vinci. Very interesting printing press exhibit. And very helpful and friendly staff. If you do not have enough time, keep your ticket and you can always return during the day.
ReviewTitle: Good for kids, not so much for adults

ReviewText: This is an amazing museum when you consider Franklin pretty much has nothing left that he actually used. There are lots of reproductions here and it's gauged for kids. Which is alright.....there is a steel frame representing where his house stood and the printing press exhibit is also good. We liked the glass tonality things as well.
Worth a look. Don't forget to stop at the printing press exhibit outside. That was the best part of the museum.

I visited the Benjamin Franklin Museum in February 2017. It is underground and I thought it was really laid out and organized well. Seeing Benjamin Franklin's bible, the chess set he played chess on, and many other artifacts was very interesting. But what stands out in my mind were his quotes and words of wisdom such as - (1) "Life is a kind of chess" (2) "A thirst for knowledge" (3) "Be frugal and industrious and you will be free" (4) "What good I have done lately". And Benjamin Franklin is known for many many quotes and words of wisdom. I definitely think this museum is worth a visit.
ReviewTitle: Great Museum - I Really Enjoyed It

ReviewText: On a beautiful weekend that called for strolling through Philadelphia history I decided to visit the Benjamin Franklin Museum and the neighborhood where Franklin and his contemporaries lived. It was great fun and reinforced one’s impression that Benjamin Franklin was a man for his times who could wear many hats at the same time. The Museum on 3rd and 4th Sts, and Chestnut and Market Sts felt like a playground for the young and curious. Did you know that Franklin was not only a seasoned diplomat and political and civic mastermind but also a curious tinkerer and can rightly be called the godfather to a number of our modern conveniences. He channeled the intricacies of electricity to our benefit; he invented a collapsible stepladder that could be folded to serve as a chair for reading the book retrieved from the top shelf with bifocals he also invented. There is much, much more to learn, and one can spend hours marveling at the mind and the ingenuity of this man who did not hesitate to use a number of pen names when it felt convenient. The Museum is adjacent to the restored site of the Market Street Houses where Franklin, his family and other families lived for a time. The houses don’t exist any longer and their value as real estate led to their sale in the early 19th century. But a “Ghost House” frame marks their location, and a clever architectural design lets you look below to follow the original foundations. Pavement stones provide further details. Do take a look at the wall display near the print shop to learn how Philadelphia expanded during the 18th century. And yes, the owner and inhabitants of these houses did have human needs to take care of and so, for example, you find a marker suggesting that the privy of the Franklin family was located here, and that a nearby water well was shared by various resident families. Philadelphia history has many twists and turns, but you can leave it to Benjamin Franklin and his Museum to explain these to you. And, even more fun, there are many hands-on features inviting you to “please touch.” Please check for opening times and enjoy!

This Museum is just off Market St in Franklin Square. It is quite large and traces the history of Benjamin Franklin and many of the activities and travels that he was involved in. There are some interactive displays that kids seem to love. Many of the displays are narrative rather than artifacts. A good museum to get an understanding of the life and times of Benjamin Franklin.
I went to the benjamin franklin museum on a rainy day. It was a very underwhelming experience. I miss some depth to the history. It's all dumbed down a bit, maybe suitable for children.

This museum is not expensive and offers a glimpse into the foresight of this great American. See some inventions and personal belongings of the great statesman. Spend anywhere from an hour to two hours exploring this well laid out attraction.

The Penn Museum is in University City (West Philly) and has fascinating collections from ancient civilizations - Assyrian, Persian, Egyptian, Etruscan, Greek, Roman, etc. You could spend all day touring the galleries with well-done displays. A special exhibition, "The Golden Age of King Midas," runs until November 27, 2016. It contains statuary, jewelry, furniture and more unearthed from tombs. You will learn about Phrygia (in modern-day Turkey) and the history of competing empires 3000 years ago. No matter how much you've studied history you will discover something new and amazing. For me it was learning about burial mounds "tumulus" (plural tumuli) and how the tombs were excavated. There is paid parking (not cheap) but you can take the westbound underground trolley from Center City to the 37th Street stop and walk a few blocks to the museum. The museum is also in walking distance from the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania and Children's Hospital. The museum is closed Monday.

We have not been here in a few years and we were unaware that there had been a MAJOR redesign. Which seems to have removed an amazing amount of artifacts. We kept looking for old favorites which were nowhere to be found and entire parts of the world have now vanished- where did all the Oceana and Arctic exhibits go? Where is the Egyptian temple? The current exhibits seem overly cluttered with large wall signs and graphics and the artifact displays were broken up into lots of smaller isolated areas which made for a disjointed viewing experience. So with the memory of what it used to be, I dithered about rating it a 3 or 4- I settled on a 4 because the quality of the artifacts is truly exceptional but the current layout is not.
ReviewTitle: It used to be much much better...

ReviewText: Excellent and very accessible archeological exhibits. Only issue was that some exhibit layouts did not historically flow from one culture to another. For example the human history setup was up in the back and out of the way of all the other exhibits. I suggest that the exhibit be placed at the entrance to the first floor. Otherwise the materials were nicely placed and clearly understandable. The cafeteria food was excellent. Witness the many employees eating there. I will get a membership to the museum since there is too much to absorb during a one shot visit. Lastly, take the kids. They may want to become archeologists after seeing the hard work involved in this career area.

The Penn Museum had some very interesting exhibits. I really enjoyed the Egyptian areas. The gardens were pretty but it was just too hot to really check them out. I do think that parking is difficult and overpriced, but that seems to be normal for Philadelphia.
This is definitely worth exploring. Well documented so you know what you're looking at. Go to the Egyptian section. One problem was no air conditioning.

Nobody who is interested in history and culture should neglect the Penn Museum in Philadelphia. Its exhibits includes items from Greek, Etruscan, Roman, Egyptian, Chinese, Japanese civilizations, etc. There are no Greek or Roman sections in the Philadelphia Museum of Art because the artifacts were loaned to the Penn Museum for exhibition on a permanent basis. If you want to see those ancient arts, you need to visit the Penn Museum. I am very impressed by its Chinese collections, especially the two stone horse reliefs which was part of the six stone horse relief commissioned by Emperor Tang Taizong of in 636 CE. I can hardly understate the importance of Emperor Tang Taizong in Chinese history. Let me put it this way: few Chinese have heard of all the Chinese emperors; however, almost all of them have heard of Tang Taizong. In fact, his dynasty (Tang) is the reason why today we still call Chinatowns all over the world as the "streets of the Tang people". Back to the story of the stone horse reliefs: the six reliefs were portraits of the beloved war-horses of Tang Taizong, and they stood right at his tomb for almost 1000 years after his death. Two of them can now be seen in the Penn Museum ! My suggestion: don't miss them for the world ! The Penn Museum has an operating lab you can see as well. When I was there, a mummy was being worked on and was placed on a table in the middle of the office. Note that the Penn Museum is rather weak on modern art. For that, you will have to visit the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
I come here every 3-4 months. I end up spending a good 5 hours each time. The Egyptian section is especially good.

As a student of Penn, I may seem biased when I say how fantastic this museum is for all interested, but it is true. Any given day there are collections of world history for our viewing pleasure. Besides, that it is the host to special events like Dias de Los Muertos which I attended last year. For all ages, it is a chance to share in Mexican culture and traditions. Then there is the archeology live Q&A about current projects. Amazing! For Penn students it is free and for the general public, it is a small price to pay to see the ancient world.
ReviewTitle: A part of history and Upenn

ReviewText: I love place, it great for adults and children. They have a large Egyptian collection and detailed explanation of what unique items are. The only bad thing I went on a 95°+ the buildings are very old and not air conditioned so it was a bit warm inside. Other than that I'm looking forward to going back at the end of Sept with my family.

In the university area, this museum houses artifacts from many cultures. The architecture of the building is beautiful .the grounds have 2 fountains, and a coi fountain. The museum houses the third largest sphinx in the world. There is an artifact lab where artifacts are stabilized for display. The staff is willing to answer questions and explain artifacts. You can touch a mummy linen, mummy skin and see Various items under magnification. The upper Egyptian hall has several statues and carvings. It has a section on mummies and science. The sphinx gallery houses the third largest sphinx as well as columns and artifacts with intricate carvings. The museum has an exhibit on evolution. There are hands on items and specimens. They currently have an exhibt on magic. The gift shop is run by a gentleman who was a huge help in finding items. They have outdoor concerts on Wednesday evenings. There cafe' has good and nutritious food. Tip:visit the sphinx, sit by the fountain, and ask about their programming.

Jurassic World was just like being in the movie. True to size animatronic dinosaurs. Could be scary for very young sensitive kids, others might love it. All the exhibits at the museum were well maintained.
ReviewTitle: FI was always great , now Jurrasic World makes it awsome.

ReviewText: This place is awesome! I can totally see becoming members here when I have kids! You can easily spend a whole day here with all the activities, stationary exhibits, and rotating exhibits. We were here for four hours since we showed up later in the day, but that time flew by and we found ourselves rushing around the museum. Be aware though that not everything is included in the admission price. The rotating exhibits, sky bike, and imax movies are an additional charge. The good thing is that if you look hard enough coupons exist for the rotational or traveling exhibits like Jurassic World for instance. We paid extra for Jurassic World, and are so glad we did because this interactive experience was a fantastic addition, and great for all ages.

We visited the Franklin Institute over Presidents Day weekend. Of the many sites we saw in Philadelphia, it was the only one that disappointed. We took two general admissions ($30 each), plus supplements for a 3D movie on space and the Jurassic World exhibit, for a total of just over $40 a person. Having never spent $40 to enter a museum, our expectation were high. The regular exhibits were more or less a collection of high school science fair experiments that had been super sized. The 3D movie used old technology and would have had the same impact in 2D. The only saving grace was the Jurassic World extra...very well done! But considering all the marvelous places to visit in Philadelphia for free or much less, the Franklin Institute would be avoided by the reincarnation of Benjamin himself, a frugal man who appreciated value.

Amazing exhibit, my boyfriend and I went for Valentine's Day weekend. Worth every penny. Dinosaurs are so life-like, at one point I even stood on the side just to get closer to the T Rex and it actually scared me!

My husband and I received tickets to The Franklin Institute and Jurassic World exhibit as part of our "Visit Philly Overnight" package. We were a little concerned as we weren't sure if the museum was geared more towards children, but we were pleasantly surprised. The Jurassic World exhibit was FANTASTIC! 100% worth the money. It was thrilling! Exciting and lots of information. The rest of the museum was equally exciting, although there certain things geared towards children my husband and I were thoroughly amused for the duration of our stay. We spent over 3 hours at the museum and only left because we had lunch reservations! I would definitely recommend The Franklin Institute to adults and children alike and would encourage shelling out the additional money for the Jurassic exhibit.
ReviewTitle: Two Adults, No Kids + Jurassic World

ReviewText: Some of the exhibits are a bit on the rundown side and need buffing up, but all in all, you can visit this place again and again and come away learning something new, and feeling like you'll want to return again fairly soon.
Great exhibition, everything was very life like. I felt like i was in the movie. I would suggest everyone who likes the movies to take the opportunity to check it out.

Went to see the art of brick and loved it. Would def go back if something unusual and exciting like that comes back on. I have referred many people to go see exhibitions. Best to become a member if you have children.

An excellent science museum. Tons of hands-on exhibits. Great for families and children. Even adults will have a good time. Quite a few Franklin artifacts scattered through out the museum. Great science store.
Totally Tourist -along with my two grandkids(13 and 12) went to the Franklin Institute to see the Pixar exhibit as well as the tour of the institute - been many times, but always enjoy

ReviewText: This is not a museum in the traditional sense. It's more of a playground on steroids. Our 3 and 7 year olds both had a blast here. Infact we got a annual memberhsip.

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131
ReviewText: Kids enjoyed the trains, construction, water exhibits, mazes, carousel, etc. Worth the membership if you make 3 visits.

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131
ReviewText: A wonderful place to visit with children. It's a small town under the roof. It has everything: shop, pharmacy, post office, railway station, hospital, building and still a lot more. Children are like in real life are buyers and sellers, postmen, doctors. There simulated real items for games and learning. You will spend with your child is a great time for 3 hours or more! Highly recommended age from 2 to 12 years.
ReviewTitle: Highly recommended age from 2 to 12 years.

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131
ReviewText: What a beautiful building! It dates from the Centennial of 1876, America's first World's Fair. But the kids will be interested in what's inside, and there is plenty to keep them busy. Our grandchildren had a great time for four hours highlighted by a "magic" show on colors. For a few extra dollars there was a magnificent restored carousel that they loved. This is perfect for rainy days - as long as the little ones have their parents along to keep an eye on the. The admission is reasonable, and the food is fairly priced and actually healthy, and that puts it in a class above so many other children's attractions.
ReviewTitle: Great for the Two through Seven Crowd

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131
ReviewText: I've been here several times and I love it more each time I go! There is so much to stimulate young minds without being overwhelming. I think the breakup of the rooms helps with that.

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131
ReviewText: Some exhibits are out of date. Great for family with kids I guess but you can definitely smell stale air and carpet especially in the basement where they have the train exhibits. The rocket launching platforms are most fun for our son. The
ReviewTitle: Family friendly but not recommend if you don't have kids

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131
ReviewText: a place where kids can run around and yell and scream and touch everything. Their current home in Memorial Hall is wonderful. That's a building that dates back to the 1800s and was a major part of the 1876 Centennial celebrations, and formerly our art museum. Be sure to check out the antique carousel!
ReviewTitle: a hands-on museum for kids in a historic building.

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131
ReviewText: Bonus if the weather isn't good for outdoor play, but a good day regardless. Loads of fun stuff for the kids and even entertaining for adults, but bring lots of hand sanitizer... It's not cheap, but a worthwhile event once in a while. I think ours was around $75 for 2adults/2kids

ProviderLocation: 4231 Ave of the Republic , Philadelphia , PA 19131
ReviewText: Be prepare to see the Willie Wonka look of amazement when your child enters this superbly organized "fun factory". If they're not hurting anyone, going to break their necks (because of the sheer amount of fun things to do), then let them try out everything in sight. If a child leaves a places and can tell you all of the fun things that happened that day then that place has succeeded at mastering the art of education thru play. Way to go Please Touch Museum.
ReviewTitle: The place where children loose their mindsâ¦ in a good way

ReviewText: The museum was larger then I thought and had a lot of history about Philadelphia's role in the ship building & naval history of our country. Couple that with a tour of the Cruiser Olympia and you have a nice day on Philadelphia's waterfront

Recently on a tour bus trip to Philly, we visited Penn's Landing and dined on the Scottish steel hulled ship Moshulu which was built in 1904 . An experience in itself. While we there we visited the exterior of the Independence Seaport museum, it was late afternoon and we didn't have a lot of time but I was amazed to see the two historic ships displayed near the museum. They are the Spanish American War cruiser USS Olympia, one of the United States' first steel warships, and the World War II submarine USS Becuna. We had to leave early the next morning so we didn't get to go inside the museum, but if all the history we saw outside was an indication as to what they had on display inside, this is definitely a place for someone that has some time and that loves Naval history as much as I do must visit. A definite must do. By the way the USS New Jersey and its museum is just across the river.
ReviewTitle: Awesome place to view naval history

ReviewText: We visited the seaport museum while touring Philadelphia for the first time. We purchased the Philadelphia pass and this was one of he attractions that were included. It's actually two attractions in one. It's the seaport museum and you also get to go inside the submarine that's in the water and also an old boat and it's all in one price! You'll need a few hour to see and read everything. It's hard to find parking but you can always either pay for a parking lot or look for meters. There's a lot of history at these attractions and you'll be amazed by a lot of it. Also when you by your ticket they let you use it for 2 consecutive days which I thought was very cool incase you running low on time or as for us since we had the Philadelphia pass and we're trying to do so many things before the pass was expired so it really worked out for us. This attraction is cool but I wouldn't say it's high priority but it's def cool so if you go I hope you enjoy! You can also walk by the marina and sit down and have lunch and relax by the water :)

We purchased our tickets through Viator to save a few bucks. To save yourself the hassle of dealing with a very unprofessional manager print your tickets out in advance! I forgot and it clearly says on the bottom of the voucher that showing it in electronic form would suffice, but he was still very rude. He kept saying since I didn't print my tickets out we are giving these tickets to you for free - not true and he could have used the barcode number. He was too lazy to do that. Instead he wanted to keep interrupting the conversation between the girl ringing me up while stuffing his face with food!! That being said - the museum itself is just ok. Besides the room that mentioned all the fires that occurred on ships in PA, DE, and NJ vicinity, this museum could exist anywhere along the east or west coast. Again really nothing special about it. What I did really enjoy was the war ships. They have two - the Cruiser Olympia and Submarine Becuna. If you pay an extra two dollars at the kiosk in front, you can have a guided tour of the Olympia instead of the self guided tour you get with your museum purchase.

Background: after arriving too early for a dinner reservation, we had some free time and walked over to the Independence Seaport Museum. It was closed, but wait, there's more! Verdict: Even when closed, there is lots of great free stuff to see while walking on the promenade. While we didn't go inside the ships, we could see the ships, read the informative displays and learn about American history through ships such as: - the Olympia Cruiser and the role it played in Teddy Roosevelt's "Walk softly and carry a big stick" gunboat diplomacy, -the Becuna, a submarine which served in both the Pacific and the Atlantic, during World War II and the Cold War. So if you're on a budget or come after hours, don't fret, there's lots to see and enjoy (for free) while walking on the promenade!
ReviewTitle: Even When Closed, Lots Of Great Free Stuff To See While Walking On The Promenade!

ReviewText: A must sea if you are interested in maritime history. A good description of the US Navy and Philadelphia as a shipyard and its role in the country's maritime history and tradition. As a former naval officer and student of history, I was drawn to the Olympia, Admiral Dewey's Flagship which prevailed in the naval Battle of Manila during the Spanish American War. The ship connected the Nineteenth Century to the Twentieth Century Naval service. The museum has a WW II which is excellent and provides a great tour as well. I too more than two hours and was not able to finish because of my interest in the subject. It is good for learning as well.
ReviewTitle: Three centuries of unique maritime history

ReviewText: Philadelphia has many historic sights to visit. On my Penn's Landing walk, I discovered the Independent Seaport Museum. Originally, I walked by then on my way back, I decided to partake. The museum is a self guided tour by following blue arrows on the ground. The blue arrows lead you into a retired war submarine then a retired war battleship docked together. The submarine scared me a little for fear of claustrophobia, but it was well lighted and practically empty so I was fine. The intricacies of the submarine was fascinating to me. I do not have a military background, but I found the machinery and engineering awesome. As someone famous said that war is hell, but war is history too. The submarine and the battleship revealed parts of history that I would not normally think about or get exposure to. The famous line, "You may fire when ready, Gridley" was actually spoken on the deck of this battleship! I highly recommend a visit to the Independent Seaport Museum for a historic walk back through time.

Except for a huge, cruddy, crowded parking lot (Walnut Street Parking) this is a great place for naval history and Philadelphia history. The museum, the cruiser Olympia, and the submarine are great. I spent nearly three hours and could have stayed longer but I had a long drive.

The attactions here are the sub and the cruiser which the sub is in decent shape but the cruiser is rumored to need very sever repairs if it is to stay afloat and the stewards have not been able to attract the enough money to deal with it. So you not allowed down into the engine spaces. The indoor museum is all posters, plaques, models handful of honest artifacts and a couple of small craft exhibits. Your also supposed to be able to go into the boat shop and watch the work, got chased out. Finally it's hidden behind the Hilton so you need to go into the parking lot next store to see it and that lot has a $20 flat rate so your paying that much for at most 2.5 hours of time. If you compare this to the mariner's museum in Newport News then it's not worth the trouble.
ReviewTitle: If your in town fine but don't make a long trip to see this.

ReviewText: It may not be the greatest seaport museum in the world, but you will not be disappointed. It is still a great place.
Went to a party sponsored by the Italian Consulate. Food was catered. The cars on display are fabulous- a car enthusiasts dream.
ReviewTitle: Beautiful classic and formular race cars in mint condition

ReviewText: How cool is it that we walked in with Dr. Simeone and he personally made sure we were welcome?! We've come here numerous times for thrilling events. Always a great visit. Safe location, free parking. Membership saves you $$$.
If you are into Italian classic cars this is a cant miss museum. From Alfa Romeo to Ferrari its a treasure of classic cars kept and stored immaculately in the museum.
One of the best car museums period. Emphasis on vintage race cars. Priceless cars that couldn't be duplicated today.
ReviewTitle: Went back for a second visit.

ReviewText: This museum is literally a shrine to race cars. It almost brought tears to my eyes when I walked into the exhibits. We attended on a Demo day, so Dr. Simeone was there to present the chosen cars for the day, and we even got to see the rare Grand Sport Corvette romp around the race area out back..in the snow. Remarkable experience that I will never forget as an automobile lover.
ReviewTitle: Amazing - no words can describe this

ReviewText: This is not flashy but basic while most of the cars are not all prettied up but in original condition - which makes it unique. Tons of history here ! A must see for anyone with even mild interest in this sort of thing . Close to PHL airport so good way to kill an extra hour or 2 .

We all need to say thanks to Dr. Simeone for building a place like this. To be able to attend his special weekends shows and to see and hear these cars running is something I have only experienced once before at Briggs Cunningham's in So. Cal. I had given up hope hearing a 4 cylinder and a 12 cylinder Italian at the same time

I had heard about this automobile museum in Philadelphia on a television show. I was planning a trip to Philadelphia and added the Simeone Automotive Museum to my list of things to see. Located in a nondescript industrial area near the Philadelphia airport, this collection of sports cars and racing machines, many have actually raced at Watkins Glen LeMans, and other venues. While some of the cars have been restored many show the patina of competition, bring racing to life. While the collection is only eight years old, but has already collected cars representing sports car racing and open wheel racing in both the United States and Europe. Stars of the collection are one of the Cobra Daytona coupes which raced at LeMans, a Ford GT which raced at LeMans, and C and D Type Jaguars. This collection represents a small but important area of automotive history. Worthwhile for any person interested in automobiles and sports car racing, as it brings what most of us only could read about.
ReviewTitle: An Overlooked Bit of Automotive History in Philadelphia

ReviewText: This is a fantastic, world-class collection of important road racing cars. These are cars that ran at classic races such as LeMans and the Nurbugring. How they all wound up in one private collection, in Philadelphia, is beyond me. If you consider yourself a sports car or racing fan, you have to see this. It is simply amazing to look closely at the real cars, not photos in a book, and to see the details.
Cant walk to it from center city, must drive , cab or Uber , still its the place to go , to see antique, beautifull autos
ReviewTitle: love cars ? you will love this place

ReviewText: We were expecting to see displays about Ghandi, Martin Luther King and others who fought for freedom of people and of speech. The displays on 'Heroes' highlighting those who gave their lives trying to help after the 9/11 attacks or those who helped Jews escape during World War 2 tied into this theme quite well although we struggled more with seeing how Carrie Fisher's bi-polar condition and others in that section fitted into a 'liberty' museum. Our real problem came with the displays on glass-making. I love glass and the Chihuly glass liberty flame is a 'must see' plus the other displays of glass are beautiful but what are they doing in a liberty museum? Unexpected although lovely to see. All in all an interesting visit but not sure how we felt about it.

Get ready to visit four levels. You will find American and international contemporary heroes and famous people (John Lennon). I was surprised facing a wonderful red famous Chihuly and a series of other glass artists' work, medium and small scale for those visitors who enjoy fine arts. The museum also includes an interesting sample of religious history, don't miss it; it's located almost hidden at the very end of a floor. A series of peace videos are also projected for visitors to enjoy. Elevators are available. There is admission charge (AAA discount)
ReviewTitle: An interesting museum that combines history and contemporary art

ReviewText: This was a neat museum but not very kid friendly. There are a lot of glass objects. I did enjoy the tid bits of information in the Be A Hero section.

On the last day of our vacation in Philadelphia, we were trying to cross off a few more items from our "to do" list for the city. It was later in the afternoon and there had been a light rain falling all afternoon. As we were passing the National Liberty Museum, we decided to step in out of the weather. Good decision! It is a Impressive museum with beautifully crafted works of art commemorating Heros who made a difference and stepped when they were needed.
ReviewTitle: Pleasant surprise after choosing the Museum to get out of the rain.

ReviewText: Good mix of art and history. Staff was very helpful. I liked that it was not as crowded as some of the other sites.

I visited the National Liberty Museum in February 2017. It is an interesting little museum. The entrance fee is $7 or $5 if you have a AAA membership. The best part of the museum is the exhibit Heroes from Around the World. I spent time here carefully looking at everything. There is also a Heroes of 9/11 Memorial exhibit.
The artistic creations were amazing ly beautiful and breathtaking. The memorial tributes to the victims of 911, Police, Fire, Military, Rescure Personnel and Civilian Respondents was very humbling.

as a local I never really knew how nice and interesting this museum to be it is modernized a little bit w/its structure but is also older in some parts to convey its historical contents --very nice museum and possibly a visit for at least 1-2 hours

On entering the museum i didnt know what to expect , you are shown into a theatre for a 10 -15 minute film on how liberty was achieved.Then you walk around various floors looking at memorabilia from different times in history, but there are also objects of differing materials like beeds , the glass is very good and not to be missed
Simple to cover if you are crunched for time. Very polite front desk staff will hook you up with a viewing and then let you loose.

This was one of the best small museums we have ever visited. Very well laid out, telling the story of Philadelphia using items in their collection. They try to give you something to think about and tell their stories from different angles - good and bad. We particularly liked the Norman Rockwell display. Staff were pleasant and helpful too. Certainly worth a visit alongside Independence Park.

The day after Thanksgiving was "Pay What You Wish" This was my 3rd time here. The 1st was before they renovated it about 20 years ago and it had quite a few informative exhibits. I looked forward to them reopening after they closed for renovations and was disappointed. It seemed a lot smaller and a lot of the old exhibits were gone. The other day I went again and nothing much changed from a few years back after the renovation. I will add that the large street map of Philadelphia was a nice part of the museum. It was worth the $1 "Pay what you wish" but not the normal $10.

I'd never been to Philly before this trip, and knew very little about it. I thought this museum was the perfect size--not overwhelmingly large, like those in DC, where I live--so we were able to get through it in about 1.5-2 hours and had the space almost entirely to ourselves (which is maybe why the smaller exhibits and rooms didn't bother us). I loved that the exhibits really drew from the quirks that make Philly the city it is, rather than conform to the formulaic "who-what-when-where-why." I also think the museum does a great job of inviting visitors to engage with artifacts in a new way, like including narratives around and reflective questions about, on their face, are simple objects but whose cultural histories hold much significance. Last, this museum does not shy away from its darker days, and calls out racism and violence against its Native American and African American residents outright--something a lot of museums are only beginning to be honest about. Last-last, the staff was super kind. All in all, a worthy visit for, at least, an out-of-town'er.
ReviewTitle: Just the right size, hyperaware of its history's bright spots and darkness

ReviewText: rather small compared to most museums, but very interesting for anyone wanting to get a sense for Philly culture and history. if you've ever lived in/near Philly, this provides plenty of nostalgia. the map of the city that you can walk around on top of is really neat. if you are in the historic section of the city, i'd highly recommend stopping by
ReviewTitle: A smaller but interesting snapshot of Philadelphia history

ReviewText: The Philadelphia History museum is small but worth visiting. The exhibits are well displayed and easy to observe. There is no feeling of being over whelmed by too much. There is a film mostly about William Penn and it is very informative about his ideal city. There are many beautiful photographs on display and an exhibit of Philadelphia's garment district. There is an elevator and several places to sit if needed.

I learned a lot about the history of the city during my visit to this museum. Their exhibitions were really top-notch, with very clear labels that encouraged me to think a lot about what they were displaying. In one gallery, especially, they made fascinating comparisons between similar objects to show Philadelphia's diversity and changes over time. For example, they had several chairs (including a bus bench, training potty, and fancy home furnishing) to show about life in different times, places, demographics, and ages. It was really thought-provoking. I visited this museum as part of the multi-museum pass during the Democratic National Convention. I absolutely recommend this museum for other visitors.
Was impressed with the ability of the staff to assist. They were very good and knew what they had. Got some great stuff done quickly

I very much enjoyed not only seeing founding memorabilia but also the thoughtfulness with which the items were displayed. The displays encourage you to do more than just look at the objects; the curators invite you to explore other stories that could have been told with the same items. Nicely done. Worth the visit. The museum is small - only reason for the 4 rating.

Wonderful unguided museum but I was told the Norman Rockwell covers for the Saturday Evening Post were there but unfortunately were not. I think they were in storage in a back room. I was able to check my coat and backpack for free and got a Senior and a AAA discount so I was a happy camper.

The Atwater Kent Museum on Philadelphia's history (named after its donator) is a rather small museum with two floors, (ground level: 3 rooms with exhibitions; first floor another 4 rooms with exhibitions) but nonetheless a place where you can easily spend more than a day. The ground-level floor features two permanent exhibitions on actual history: first a room that showcases a movie about William Penn, and Philadelphia's and Pennsylvania's foundation providing a detailed story, a large floor-map of the center of Philadelphia, and a composition of photos from the past and the present; second a room with a timeline which gives a rough insight into Philadelphia's history after that. The third room houses changing exhibitions, I assume, always about a volunteer organisation that influences the community (the museum store has published a book about that topic, available there, I think). When I was there on November 28, this room's exhibition was about an art project for children and youths with latin american social background, called Taller Puertorriquen~a (please read this symbol ~ above the 'n'). I as a tourist found this exhibition very interesting, the social effects of this program gave me a very deep insight into art and its meanings, possibilities, and potential. The complete second floor features another permanent exhibition about objects and the (hi)story/stories they tell. It is basically a large collection of different objects (like the boxing gloves of a famous Philadelphian boxer, Benjamin Franklin's fireglass, a grandfather clock of another famous (late) citizen of Philadelphia). To each object its original, encyclical definition/description and use, the real story that is known that it tells, and the piece of Philadelphian history covered by/connected to that, is given. Furthermore, the question is asked what other stories the object on hand might tell, along with a few examplatory answers. Although I had not the time to see everything (I had "only" a 10 hour layover in Philadelphia), I found this museum very intriguing (and definitely worth the $10 charged for adults). I regret, that I could not spend more time there than I have, and will visit again, if I come again to Philadelphia.

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: The outside is a tip as to the wonders that await. The architecture and art inside are a feast with a balanced mix of old and new, there is sculpture, painting and mixed media (video, too) set in a working school. We did not set aside enough time and will return when we go back to Philly.

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: The Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and the great artists and curators in its rich history make this one of the absolute go-to destinations in the United States. And internationally for that matter. The Frank Furness designed buildings with those incredible windows only enhance the experience. There are floors and buildings of exhibits and the special installations, like the WWI Exhibition which we just saw, can be jaw-dropping. Here is our routine: A coffee or tea and pastry first in their fine little cafe "Au Table at PAFA". (music at the cafe is kind of cool...perfectly in keeping with the surroundings), Next step: Savor one area...either the special collection or one of the wings. For us, trying to absorb the whole place in one fell swoop is overwhelming. Then on to the gift shop. By the way, due to a grant, Sundays are free here until April.
ReviewTitle: So Much to Absorb in this Icon

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: PAFA is always great, but the current exhibit of World war I art is just amazing. It follows the war from inception to the end and demonstrates every possibly reaction and emotion. We really enjoyed it. They have a nice cafe where we had lunch.

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: The Frank Furness architecture would be enough to warrant a visit. Throw in a good permanent collection and terrific special exhibits, and you have a site worth coming to Philadelphia for. The Barnes, The Art Museum, and Pennsylvania Academy are an art lovers dream. Take the time to explore many of the local galleries as well. Philly is more than just history.
ReviewTitle: One of the great small art museums, ANYWHERE.

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: My spouse and I have visited the PAFA several times in 2016. We just saw World War I and American Art. The exhibit was comprehensive, detailed and included different media include oil and water color painting, photography and even a silent animation. The exhibition was education and also emotionally touching,
ReviewTitle: Special exhibitions are worth a look

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: On my last day in Philly I made a quick last minute stop at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts (PAFA). I'm so glad I did. I only had time to see the current exhibit of WW1 art which is a wonderfully curated show of artwork and commentary surrounding this important era. There is much to see in the rest of the museum and I'll be sure to spend more time there on my next visit. The display outside the museum of the WW1 airplane was especially moving and thought-provoking. And a Dick Blick store right on campus was an added bonus!

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: The museum does not have a massive collection but what was in the building was interesting. There was a mix of modern and historical works including a number of portraits and sculptures of former Presidents. I attended the museum on a Sunday and the admission cost on that day was free.
ReviewTitle: Small Museum but a good selection of American Art

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: PAFA’s current exhibit World War I and American Art and its impact on American artists is thought provoking and so I went to learn how John Singer Sargent, Childe Hassam, Georgia O’Keefe, Clagget Wilson and many other less known artists incorporated war into their art. I also discovered Horace Pippin (1888-1946), the self-taught, deeply human African-American artist who served in France during WW I. He is one of the very few participants in this exhibit who served and therefore can speak with particular urgency and candor. Pippin was deeply scarred by his war experiences and, with his right arm wounded and crippled for life, Pippin was dispatched home in 1919, to an uncertain emotional and material existence. It was not until the mid-1930s that he returned to modest attempts at painting, inventing ways to use his crippled arm. By picking up paint and brush again he hoped to combat his frequent “blue spells” that had troubled his memory and psyche for so long. Two pictures in this exhibit are poignant testimonies to his experiences. They are “End of War: Starting Home” worked on between 1930-33; and “Barracks,” painted in 1945. In their simple forms and with an intuitive sense of dignity, color, proportion and essentials of story telling Pippin was eventually able to silence his demons and move on. Pippin became a well known African American painter with solo shows in major museums and paintings of various genres in public and private collections. He remained a modest man to the end of his life, devoted to his family as well as his God. He died where he had been born, in Chester, Pennsylvania, a short distance from Philadelphia. He always painted with the same motivation: “Pictures come to my head and I tell my heart to go ahead.” World War I and American Art will be at PAFA until April 9, 2017.
ReviewTitle: World War I and American Art: Horace Pippin

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: The Academy building is worth a visit in and of itself but the collection is the real star - a great overview of the development of American art from its earliest beginnings. Well worth a visit for those interested in art. For the casual visitor the impressive stair hall might be enough!

ProviderName: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
ReviewText: Everyone seems to know about the Philadelphia Museum of Art but they don't know about PAFA. I love the intimacy of this museum. It's worth coming here for the building itself. It's a gem. I am a member & come regularly. They do an excellent job of changing it up so that the regulars don't get bored. They are open til 9 on Wednesdays. They have special events. It's a great time to come b/c, if you get lucky, it will feel like you have the museum to yourself. They have some reasonably-priced, fun classes, too.

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: I had not been here in 30 years. Children love it. I prefer live animals to dead ones, but I was at the academy for a private party. The dinosaur exhibits were interesting. As were African animals. See my photos.

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: We had the privilege of visiting the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia this past week. What a wonderful museum for kids of all ages. We especially loved the dioramas of the animals AND the butterfly room. They also have a great dinosaur display. The staff were so friendly and helpful. My husband and I had a perfectly enjoyable day exploring all that this museum has to offer.
ReviewTitle: Great Place to Visit in Philadelphia

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: There are plenty of exhibits to see. You also can watch a movie or grab a bite to eat. Sometimes, you run into kids on a school trip, which makes it noisy, but it's still fun.
ReviewTitle: The Academy of Natural Sciences is a wonderful museum.

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: I love the Academy! They are so up to date on all the things necessary to educate the public on all things natural! I try to keep an annual membership to the Academy to support their efforts of educating the public and mainly children. The DVOC (Delaware Valley Ornithological Club) holds their meeting here and has been since 1891. As the Gala coordinator, I worked with the Academy to hold our 125th Anniversary Gala at the Academy. As a venue, this place can't be beat! As a place to visit it is so much fun for kids and grown-ups alike. We consider the Academy to be part of our family. We love the bug exhibits, the butterfly exhibit, the Dinosaur Hall, which is fascinating and captivating, and most of all we love holding our bird club meetings here on a regular basis. Drexel University did a great job of bringing together the worlds of biology, ornithology, entomology and research then blending them all to create the finest collections in the world. We honestly think everyone should try to visit the Academy of Natural Sciences, especially if you are a local. You should always appreciate the treasures in your backyard. This one is vital to our science knowledge and has great programs you can participate in as well!

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: Natural Sciences, come-on, who wouldn't be amazed at the composition and variety of this museum? My spouse came here often as a young lady and it is just as amazing and interesting today. Great for families and many attractions are geared towards children. Enjoy

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: I had a few hours to kill in Philadelphia but have in previous visits stopped by most of the best known museums. So I tried this one Dinosaurs are not my thing but there were a number of children that seemed to be enjoying these exhibits. That left a number of wildlife dioramas -- a media that offers limited appeal in this age of Wikipedia and online videos.
ReviewTitle: Strong on Dinosaurs, Not Too Much Else

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: I always stop here when I come down. I love the dinosaurs. The new exhibit dinosaurs unearthed was interesting and awesome. Loved the animatronics. There was a staff member giving a short program on the dinosaurs. Loved the Egyptian mummy and dioramas. There were several programs in the auditorium. Staff was very accomadating and eager to help. The security staff went out of there way to help me and hold my luggage. They helped me locate my lost phone as well. The cafe'was good with sandwich and nutritious options.
