Loved the butterfly habitat. Spent a ton of time in there . Tips: see the dinosaur hall first, and start on 3rdfloor working your way down. Weekends they are open until 5pm. Ask about special programs.

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: Given the price I paid, including the extra for the Tarantula exhibit, I found a bit pricy and a lot smaller than I expected. The regular exhibits are quite nice, and interesting, but I pretty much saw everything in just over an hour, including the butterflies. The extra fee for seeing the Tarantulas was absolutely not worth the price. The exhibit, while nice, is very small and takes only minutes to see. I was very disappointed in this aspect in particular. For what I paid, I was honestly expecting it to be about double the size that is actually is. I don’t know that I’d come here again. Lots of kids were here from local schools, and they did seem to be enjoying themselves.
ReviewTitle: Nice Place, but Smaller than Expected

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: We had tickets from Smithsonian Day and went on a date! It was cute and fun! Plan bathroom trips carefully and bring your own water (bottled water and drinks are expensive!!). It was very fun and a nice way to spend a rainy and dank day in Philly.

ProviderName: Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
ReviewText: Enjoyed taking the time to see and read all the exhibits without young children along. The tarantula exhibit revealed many facts I did not know before. Loved seeing the variety of animals. Especially like the bee exhibit that allows the worker bees to come in and out. I also spoke at length with a volunteer who works on the fossils. Everyone is friendly. I suggest coming during the week when it is cold and less people.

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: We love university archaeology museums and this is one of the best....right up there with U. of Chicago's Oriental Institute. A very worthwhile hour.
ReviewTitle: One Of The U.S.'s Best Museums

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: I love this place! I hate that non-students have to pay for admission but it is worth it. They have all the originally artifacts from Ur, like the ram in the thicket and headdress of Queen Puabi. They also have a mummy conservation room where you can watch the experts at work.

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: This is acollection of archaeological artefacts, either in showcases or free-standing, depending on their size. The depth of explanation varies as the climate. There are air-conditioned galleries and not A/C ones. This roller-coaster floated us through the entire museum without leaving any deeper mark.

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: This was our single favorite attraction. The exhibits, (Chinese, Egyptian, Mesopotamia, as well as North and South America) are minimal. But none of that matters because they have MUMMIES. Best of all, there is an actual conservationist who answers questions and gives incredible insight to the process of preservation. These sessions are timed and the times differ from weekday to weekend hours. We were done with the museum-proper in a little over an hour but waited an additional hour for the opportunity to speak with the conservationist and I’m SO glad we did. Molly gave us tremendous detail into university efforts to preserve and maintain the human remains as well as the antiquities in the collection. Check schedules online and make sure you attend one of these great sessions. We would most definitely do this again. *Side note on the staff* their AC was out and it was a very warm day. The docent selling tickets insisted we take two bottles of water. Everyone was very helpful and encouraging. They want folks to know about this incredible collection.

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: This is a great way for almost everybody to learn about past civilizations and current cultures. The building is also worth seeing with it's marble stairways and red-brick designs. They don't build buildings like this anymore!
ReviewTitle: the building alone is worth it.

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: I am so fortunate to live just a short walk from the Museum of the University of Pennsylvania. It is very possibly the best such museum in the country. You can visit ancient Egypt, learn about Persian history and the ruler Hasanlu, and even visit ancient China! The museum really is a friendly place for the Anthro/Archaeology nerd in all of us. Easy to reach, and they even have a great cafeteria.
ReviewTitle: One of the Greatest Anthropology/Archaeology Museums in the USA

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: The University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology's most unique feature is the colossal rotunda that is the largest masonry dome in the country. The collection is pretty good, although not spectacular. The building is the real appeal here. Only problem is that it's extremely stuffy, and I had difficulty breathing.

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: Great collection and experts people around all the floors and departments. Have collection of different archeological artifacts from Middle east, Caribbean Islands, and other North American countries including the USA. Urban tourist will love spending some quality time in the museum.

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: This is a museum with a wide collection but it seems to be a bit static in places. It's comparatively inexpensive. The building is quite dated - a merger of two largely incompatible architectures. As for location it's a perfectly doable, 2-ish mile walk from city hall. There are also lots of cabs, unless it's raining. Much of the archaeologic content is built from loot from digs from the early 20th century, and from both older and more recent collections of content The egyptian, etruscian, and greek exhibits don't appear to have been updated in years and shows it (the facility - not the content - the content is great!). Some exhibits are done via photography - large, lovely prints of Byzantine art, for example. The special exhibits are more interesting, though sometimes the curation is a bit odd. In one visit we found a collection of posters in the basement discussing African Americans in propaganda which had some rather poorly thought out comments about favorable Soviet treatment of minorities that seemed to have been taken by the curator at face value. Plenty of good food nearby - food trucks, take out, restaurants on or near Penn's or Drexel's campus. Don't eat in the museum.
ReviewTitle: Special exhibits are generally good. Some permanent exhibits are a bit dated.

ProviderName: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology
ReviewText: The Archaeology & Anthropology Museum on the University of Pennsylvania campus in Philadelphia is a must see. I live in the suburbs of Philadelphia and have been there on several occasions. The Egyptian mummies are amazing! What the Egyptians knew about embalming bodies is fascinating. There are collections of artifacts from many countries around the world. I enjoyed the African exhibit because there were artifacts from the tribe I lived with while teaching in Sierra Leone, West Africa. Johanna J Smith, MA, LPC
ReviewTitle: Tour of the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology & Anthropology

ProviderLocation: Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia , PA Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia, PA
ReviewText: We didn't have a reservation but we were seated right away. I do recommend making one. It filled up right after we got there. Service was good. Friendly staff. I had a salad with Scottish smoked salmon on top. It was delicious!!

ProviderLocation: Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia , PA Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia, PA
ReviewText: Chose this over the cafeteria. Nice setting, very efficient service. Had the daily special of wild muhsroom and cheddar quiche with salad. The quiche was meiocre at best, needed a bit of zest. The salad was even blander. Wich there had been s&p on the table!

ProviderLocation: Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia , PA Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia, PA
ReviewText: In the classic 1986 film, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, the film's star reminds his friend of all they had seen that day. "We've seen the whole city! We went to a museum! We saw priceless works of art! We ate pancreas!" Thirty years later, I still like Ferris' idea of a good time. I've just completed a long weekend in Philadelphia that included most of the high points of the infamous day off: 2 Phillies games, 3 amazing dinners, 2 great luncheons, 2 art museums, architecture and a beautiful woman (my wife). I swapped the red Ferrari element for Uber Black service to avoid the whole parking garage fiasco and exchanged the Chicago parade for fireworks over the Delaware River. Now for the review. The Philadelphia Museum of Art is a darned good swap for the Art Institute of Chicago featured in the film - plus you get to replicate Rocky Balboa's pose on the museum steps. Spend the morning looking at priceless (and sometime iconic) masterpieces and enjoy a relaxing luncheon at Granite Hill restaurant located on the first floor of the museum. Then finish your visit with a tour of a few more rooms of the museum. The food in the restaurant is very good - although pancreas (a/k/a sweetbreads) was not on the menu [I suggest a visit to Bibou or Amis for that element). Granite Hill also offers cocktails which may help novices to better appreciate the museum's modern art collection. In closing, I'll just remind you of our hero's motto, "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."
ReviewTitle: Ferris would have approved of this luncheon

ProviderLocation: Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia , PA Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia, PA
ReviewText: Easy to find with a lovely menu, nice desserts, calm environment. Limited hours to lunch and dinner.
ReviewTitle: A nice surprise for a museum dining option

ProviderLocation: Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia , PA Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia, PA
ReviewText: 3rd visit and was sorry. Hard rolls placed on table, requested change, got the same back. Server was trying hard to do nothing. Asked for dressing on side of entree salad, never happened. I had the buffet, had to ask for clean dishes from different server.Simply a case of benign neglect and the ahi tuna on buffet was tasteless.

ProviderLocation: Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia , PA Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia, PA
ReviewText: Even the most seasoned museum goer sometimes needs to take a break for a bite. The Philadelphia Museum of Art is well prepared and offers sustenance at several venues, from cafeteria to Balcony Cafes, and more formal yet casual dining at Granite Hill, the Museum’s full-service restaurant on the ground floor. I choose Granit Hill since I not only wanted a tasty lunch but also have an opportunity to rest my feet, read my brochures and focus on what I had seen and wanted to remember. I was not disappointed. The Granite Hill restaurant is spacious and well lit with tables for 2 or more diners placed at a respectful distance. The focal point at lunch is the Chef’s Table, offering an ample spread of lunch meats, cheeses, salads and accoutrements to fashion your eclectic meal. The regular menu also offers many choices from starters such as Saffron-Scented Prince Edward Island mussels; a variety of appetizing salads such as the Hot Smoked Scottish Salmon; and luscious sounding main courses such as Grilled Pennsylvania Brook Trout. I chose the Scottish smoked salmon salad. It was nicely presented, appetizing and properly seasoned. Satisfied, I passed on desert. After having thus refreshed myself in body and mind I felt energized to continue museuming and visit the redesigned and recently reopened Asia galleries on the second floor. The staff at Granite Hill is cheerful and competent, the wait between ordering and receiving your meal is timely, and your bill will be appropriate for service received. Bon appétit!
ReviewTitle: Dining with art treasures around you at Granite Hill

ProviderLocation: Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia , PA Benjamin Franklin Parkway , Philadelphia Museum of Art , Philadelphia, PA
ReviewText: After visiting few galleries a stop at the Granite Hill was a welcome brake. Good service. Sometimes they served food complimenting an exhibition. They have a menu or a buffet style. Good brunch on Sunday.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: I did not read anything about this museum before going. I found the content to be very informative but the historic aspect seemed to stop at the end of the 19th century. I also enjoyed the art associated with Ntozake Shange's writings. Many of the exhibits on the ground floors are children friendly.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: We enjoyed hours of history at the informative, African American Museum in Philadelphia, PA. The beautiful sculptures, paintings and especially the many video presentations which were memorable and uplifting. I highly recommend this historical Philly attraction. Enjoy your visit.
ReviewTitle: Visited the African American Museum in Philadelphia, PA.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: I've always wanted to visit the African American museum as I've driven past numerous times. My husband and I were sorely disappointed. Two levels had no exhibits at all and were being painted. We should have been informed when paying admission that this was the case. There is so much history to share and inform the public about that it's hard to understand such a lack of displays during a time tourists are still visiting Philly. I hope the museum can do better in the future.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: While in Philly for a convention, we walked around downtown and went to the African American Museum. The Cost was 14.00 for both of us with our AAA discount. The museum had 3 floors that were open and a total of maybe 6 exhibits. While interesting, we kinda expected to see more African American history.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: I was skeptical when I entered but.....I paid the price anyway (I should have followed my instincts). I tried to make my visit last an hour so that could feel that I got something out of it. Did not happen. No artifacts or anything of historical value. Just some paintings and other bits and pieces of random items that were not displayed properly to draw any interest. Very disappointing since there is so much African American history in culture in Philadelphia. The first floor exhibit Audacious Freedom - was actually good. The video walls of prominent Philadelphia African Americans was ok but it was cumbersome to have to press buttons and sit through every presentation to get a full story - design flaw. There is a lot of wasted space in this museum. This museum will not last long if more is not added to it that will make people want to come.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: The exhibits documented in this museum are so important for everyone to experience. It's a great piece of American history, relevant to Philadelphia, the state that has seen so many monumental occurrences. Definitely worth a visit!

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: I was very excited about visiting this museum. It is located in China town. The front desk receptionist was very nice and offered my a military discount which came to about $7.00 (half adult price). As soon as you enter there is a large timeline exhibit which was interesting. It had a voice over that came on and briefly described some of the historic events. You go up a ramp and there is a display with about 8 historical figures. You press the buttons and a actor portraying that person comes on and tells a good bit of info about that person and their contribution to society, specifically the Philadelphia area. You head up another ramp or two and you are on the 3rd level. There were not a lot of exhibits and I was kind of upset that that was it. Nonetheless the exhibits that were on display were very powerful and centered on black feminism. Overall I just wish there was more to the exhibits. It literally only took me about 35-40 mins and that's with me taking time to read and absorb EVERY exhibit.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: I was delighted to have this institution available that tells the story of the role that African Americans played in the development of Philadelphia. The most memorable display for me was the silent bells in front of the museum that signify the silent, ongoing struggles of African Americans. There's a $14 entrance fee to visit, but when I visited it was 50% off due to the fact that one of the four galleries was not open to the public because of a private event. While there were some interesting, interactive audio/visual timelines and historic individuals central to the struggle, I would have loved to have seen more original photographs and artifacts. These are essential in connecting the past with the present. I also believe that there should be street signage (similar to those that lead to Independence Historic Park and the larger Philadelphia Museum) to increase foot traffic to the institution. Overall, I'm proud that this institution exists and hope to see more original artifacts when I visit again.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: This museum takes a deeper look into the like of black philadelphians. It covers different areas such as slavery, business, religion, politics, family and general day to day life. For $14 I expected something slightly better, I enjoyed my visit nonetheless. The first floor is the most interesting and has a exhibition which showcases the lives of some philadelphians from that era.
ReviewTitle: Great insight into the history of black philadelphians.

ProviderName: The African American Museum in Philadelphia
ReviewText: This museum celebrates African American history and culture through exhibitions and video presentations. There was a powerful exhibit called Cash Crop (don't know for how long) -- 15 life size sculptures of people in shackles to convey the experience of being kidnapped into slavery.

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: Just go. The crash course in American history through the Constitution, Bill of Rights and subsequent amendments, is as deep or simple as you want to make it. The 360 degree film included in the ticket price, is the best introduction to what awaits outside in the circular hall that winds through time up until the end of the Obama administration. Prepare to be educated, awed, moved and challenged as you view our countries history through the changing culture as reflected in the changes to our most important document.

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: We had a good time going around to see the main exhibits and almost left when we saw around the corner on the second floor, something called Signers’ Hall. This has bronze statues with the signers of the Constitution as they would look in Independence Hall. The sculptures used portraits and descriptions to make them looks as accurate as possible. You can touch the sculptures and take pictures with your favorites. Just behind the hall is also a room with one of the first prints of the Constitution. These two rooms are hidden away, make sure to go see them!

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: This is fairly good museum dedicated to the history of the constitution. The main drawback to the center is that it is fairly expensive. You do get to see a show though and enjoy the museum, so it is certainly worth it. My main disappointment was that it had not been updated in the several years since I had last been there so many of the interactive elements were either out of date or not working as they should. That being said it is a really great place to introduce kids to the concepts at work in the constitution and I really like the founders hall where you can sign it yourself.
ReviewTitle: Good information, history, and opportunities to think

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: Great exhibits and learning tools to understand how our country began, our laws, rights and changing horizons

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: This center was all encompassing, totally worth going to. It even has a room with life-size bronze statues of the signers of the Declaration of Independence.

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: Through exhibits and performances, this center brings the constitution to life. Easy to learn how our form of government works as well as the history of the presidential race. Make sure to catch the show, it really makes you think.

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: I visited the National Constitution Center in August 2016 (somehow I forgot to write a review of it). It is a fantastic place and definitely worth a couple of hours. There was a special exhibit on presidential campaigns and elections. The separate exhibit on the powers of the president was very interesting. And on the second floor there were many exhibits and explanations on the US constitution itself. Besides the various amendments and the core part of the US constitution, I remember the oath of citizenship. Again I highly recommend a visit here during a visit to Philadelphia.

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: I visiting the Constitution Center by myself as I had time to kill. The beginning presentation is fantastic and I love how takes you straight through time. You sort of get lost in all the facts that I forgot where I was for awhile. The wealth of information is amazing and it is interactive enough for you young students so they don't zone out. The people there were very knowledgeable, makes me want to brush up on my history a bit before I go again!

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: This was my favorite place to visit - very educational and the exhibits were well done and accessible. It was a great reminder to me about the history of our constitution.

ProviderLocation: 525 Arch St , Independence Mall , Philadelphia , PA 19106-1595
ReviewText: The Contitution Center was very informative and made interesting for all with a very good narrative light show. The interactive attractions made history real for adults and students-being sworn in as president, donning supreme court robes, etc

Fireman's Hall - sitting on the Second Street. Is the oldest firemen station in the city. It is maintained so well, that some of the celebrities could get jealous! Just a few steps to the left - towards the end of the block - and you can take your selfie with the replicas of Elvis Presley and Charlie Chaplin with this Fireman's Hall in the background!! There's no other spot like that!
ReviewTitle: Fireman's Hall - sitting on the Second Street

ReviewText: I thought this was a cool museum. They have dedications to the 9/11 firefighters, which we went to the Flight 93 Memorial after we left here, so it felt appropriate. They also have some cool old firefighting equipment and trucks. You can try on firefighting boots and jacket and it's geared towards families. It's a tour on your own facility. It's also free but we gave a donation.

I loved this museum. I didn't realise it was on two floors. I didn't realise there were so many exhibits. I thought it was just old fire engines and tenders! There was an interesting video about segregated fire stations. I loved the memorial for fire men and women who had lost their lives. There is no charge for the museum but a donation is asked for. If you have a child who wants to be a fireman, this place would be heaven for them!

So...I am engaged to a fireman; it was a no brainer for us to stop in here and check this place out. I must say that it was well done and family friendly place to go. They have activities for the kids on both levels and the old apparatus downstairs that will get their attention. There is also a 9-11 tribute and the stained glass window with lots of history throughout. Set up like a real firehouse with real firemen at the desk to talk to. Worth a look and it is free. Donations are appreciated.

Tucked away from the busy area this is a great way to learn about the fire station and get to meet some friendly locals. Kids & Big kids can try on some of the firemans uniform for some cool pictures.

If you like fire fighters, this is the place for you. This is a well put together 2 story exhibit within walking distance of other Old City attractions. It contains a combination of Philadelphia fire fighting history as well as fire fighting in general. There is a lot of fire fighting equipment to look at, including some really old "fire trucks". The museum is free, but they do ask for a donation.

Get out at 2nd street station subway and walk up 2nd street past the famous Elfreth alley and you will find it on the same side,(15 mins walk) from the subway. Entrance is at the side. It is free but they ask for a donation not directly there is a sign asking for a donation. It is on two floors and has lifts,great collection of old fire engines and a moving item to do with 9/11.
ReviewTitle: A good museum worth a visit

ReviewText: Fireman's Hall seems to be off the beaten path, located only one block south of the Ben Franklin Bridge. The highlights are the vintage fire engines, the 9/11 exhibit and memorial, and the stained glass, surprisingly. It's free, but they want a donation. Also, very kid friendly.

Tucked away on a street not too far form the main hustle of the touristy things, this museum is accessed via a side door down an alley. The free (donations recommended) museum is fabulous. It talks about the history of firefighting and shows much of the history through artifacts and displays! MUST see!

I only discovered this museum by chance when someone mentioned this was nearby Elfreth's Alley which I was planning to visit. This small fire fighters museum is housed in a disused fire station which is delightful with its fire fighters themed stained glass windows. There is a fascinating collection of old fire engines, uniforms, photographs and fire fighting equipment. There are interactive displays and opportunities for children to dress up in fire fighting clothing. The museum is free to visit although donations are appreciated. The staff are there to welcome you and answer any questions you have. I am really pleased to have visited and would highly recommend a visit here.

My wife and I are book people, so on a recent visit to Philadelphia we were very interested to see Rosenbach's house and library, as well as the modern library where I wanted to arrange to do some research.The fact that they had a little Oscar Wilde exhibit on seemed a plus, though we never would have gone for that alone. We researched the library on the web and learned that by going on the hour we could get a tour of the house and library, which are otherwise not accessible. We accordingly timed our visit so that we arrived just before 3 PM. However, the clerk hemmed and hawed about whether we would be able to see the house and library because somebody was sick and somebody else might or might not be available to cover the reception desk for him. Meanwhile he encouraged us to view the Wilde exhibit upstairs, while he arranged the rest. We accordingly paid the not inexpensive admission fee, spent a few minutes in the two-room Wilde exhibit, and came back to hear about further arrangements. Someone was phoned (which could have been done while we were at the Wilde exhibit, or when we entered originally), and 10 minutes later we learned that no one would be available to take us to the house and library for another 45 minutes, which was impossible for us. As it turned out, the librarian in the modern library was away at a conference, so we could not go there either. We were never offered our money back and left feeling frustrated and thoroughly put off by the experience. I would describe it as friendly incompetence.

Having been to most every museum in Philly, we were looking to fill some time with a visit to the Rosenbach. It's hard to believe we had passed this by. It's truly a treasure trove of American history with a priceless book collection as the centerpiece. And a great house museum and family history to boot. Props to the docent(s) - they bring the place to life.

A must see for Maurice Sendak fans as well as those who enjoy seeing turn of the century homes. It also has an amazing collection of rare books available for review and research. It's in a nice neighborhood and provides an interesting way to spend a few hours off the beaten track.
The museum has an incredible collection of literary works which they won't let you see. The staff is down right rude and impertinent.
a good destination for book lovers or just people who like big old townhouses. Fascinating even for the noncollector
ReviewTitle: offbeat, quirky mansion filled with books

ReviewText: The good things here are that there is an excellent collection of books and also memorabilia from famous authors, including James Joyce and Bram Stoker. The rooms are also beautiful. The only downside is that tours are mandatory. Ugh.
ReviewTitle: Pretty Good, as far as small museums go...

ReviewText: I came here for the small, but well-curated Oscar Wilde exhibition, but was wowed by a superb docent-led tour (Martha, I believe?) of the home and personal collection of book dealers Phil and Abe Rosenbach (who helped JP Morgan and other wealthy individuals build their own private libraries). What a gem of a place just a couple of blocks south of Rittenhouse Square!
ReviewTitle: Heaven for Any Antiquarian Book Enthusiast

ReviewText: I've been to the Rosenbach twice -- my son used to live a couple of blocks away, so we took the tour together one day. He was dubious, but ended up being very glad he went. There is a wealth of things to look at: portraits of the Gratz family, the Rosenbach brothers, et al; maps and art objects; beautiful furniture. There is a small exhibit about Frances Anne Kemble, the English actress who married a slave-owner from Georgia and wrote a book about it. And of course, there are the books! The Rosenbachs had superb taste in everything, and the book collection is amazing. The second time I visited, I looked at every spine (I think) and asked to have a Cotton Mather manuscript pulled out so I could just cast my peepers upon it. Amazing! One has to make an appointment 2-3 weeks in advance in order actually to be able to read a book; that's my next visit. My son moved to Chicago, more's the pity... .

How often do you get a chance to visit a great 4 story Philadelphia mansion in one of the classiest sections of the city. The houses were built in the 1860s and Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach lived here for over 25 years until he died in 1952. During that time, he and his brother bought, sold and collected classic books, original manuscripts and decorative arts much of which can be seen in the house, museum and library. The house has been moderized in some ways with an elevator, rest rooms, etc, however, much of the classic style remains with some original furniture, great paintings (one room has paintings by famous American artist Thomas Sully of members of the Gratz family, who were well known in Philadelphia), original manuscripts such as James Joyce's Utysses and Lewis Carroll's Alice in Wonderland. In the vast library they also have the only original copy of Benjamin Franklin's Poor Richard's Almanac. The mansion is visited by means of a guided tour with an excellent tour guide, then you are allowed in some of the galleries on your own, especially to see the work of Maurice Sendak, who gave the museum much of his work and some of his whimsical pictures are on display. This place is a real find and a joy to visit. Entrance fee is $10. It is associated with other museums as part of the North American Reciprocal Museums, so membership in one of those museums allows for free entrance.
ReviewTitle: Wonderful mansion turned into museum and library

ReviewText: Maurice Sendak, Herman Melville, Marianne Moore and James Joyce! Such exalted company, all in one exceptional small museum! Housed in the former home of the Rosenbach brothers, now a small gem of a museum, there are both book and decorative arts treasures to amuse and delight anyone interested in furniture, object d'art and especially rare and beautiful books. A favorite haunt!

Stately, beautiful building with some interesting exhibits. Learned some new things about American history and the Swedes. Was able to see and touch one of those chain vests that the vikings (and others) wore as armor back in the day. Boy is it heavy!! Enjoyed the visit. Worth the admission price of $8.00 for adults. Located in a big beautiful park drive through park. Free parking right in front of the building too!!!

This is one of my favorite museums in Philadelphia. It's a stately building in a beautiful park setting near the Navy Yard. The area around Philadelphia was once called Little Sweden and the museum tells that story. It also has changing exhibits that always are interesting. It also has an interesting Swedish gift shop. Watch the web site for special lectures, day trips or festivals and dinners. They are always fun and always welcoming!

Nice museum in Franklin Delano Roosevelt Park in South Philadelphia. Very nice exhibits and well worth the admission price. There seemed to be a nice area for kids and activities set through out the exhibits to keep them entertained or interested. Not a very large museum so it should only take a couple hours if that. Great venue for a wedding or a party as well.
ReviewTitle: Visit if You Have the Opportunity

ReviewText: We were lucky to have been directed to this fine museum by a brochure we saw at the Simeone Auto Racing Museum. The two museums are relatively close together on the south side and the exhibit was about Indian Motorcycles. We went to see the motorcycles and were treated as well to a well presented museum about the contributions of Swedes to America. The rooms on the second floor are dedicated to individuals who make contributions to their adopted country. In the main floor, there is a map room as well as an exhibits of textiles, farm tools and life in the new world. The front door is locked and you must ring to gain entrance, but your patience is amply rewarded.
ReviewTitle: Excellent tribute to a fine Swedish American heritage.

ReviewText: I didn't know this museum existed after living on and off in the area for quite some time. I was surprised when I found it on Groupon. I don't think I've ever even met someone who claims Swedish ancestry. The museum is across from the FDR park in South Philly, so the grounds and landscape is beautiful. The "back" of the building, where the entrance and parking are located, is so beautiful! When we entered, we were promptly greeted by a wonderful employee. She was so cheerful and made us feel so welcomed. She told us some information about the building and the layout of the museum. She invited us back to visit whenever, attend events, or become a member. Based on our interactions with her alone, the museum was a hit and I would become a member! The exhibits were very interesting. It is information that we never hear or learn about. I didn't know of any Swedish presence in this area of the US. The history of emigration from Sweden to the US was so interesting. There was a lot of important cultural aspects and traditions displayed as well. It was a great visit and we will be back, especially for the events. I may become a member soon! I will recommend it to everyone!

This is a great museum! I didn't make the connection of Swedish settlers in this area until I saw this museum, and I really learned a lot going through it. I recommend it, especially if you enjoy Scandinavian history or have it in your blood!

We discovered this small, but interesting museum through an article in a local city paper. It is of particular interest to anyone studying or involved in the practice of chemistry. It is a walk through the development of chemical study and its relationship to our daily lives. Somewhat curious.
ReviewTitle: Little known museum featuring a history of chemical study.

ReviewText: As someone with a chemistry background we made a point to stop into the Chemical Heritage Foundation museum. As a small but free museum there were plenty of displays to provide some interesting insights into chemical history. From the historic early instrumentation to the individual displays devoted to Bakelite and Nylon there is plenty to teach something new. My only disappointment was the lack of any displays devoted to the many American nobel laureates in Chemistry that would make an excellent addition to this museum.
ReviewTitle: Step back into Chemical History Here

ReviewText: If you're a science nerd like me, Philadelphia has some awesome places to offer, including the Chemical Heritage Foundation. This place is free admission ($5 suggested donation) and has some older chemistry laboratory equipment as well as an interactive screen that details some famous chemists and the elements. They also hold lectures here. It's very interesting and can be done in about 40 minutes.
ReviewTitle: Science nerd? You'll LOVE this place

ReviewText: The square footage of this museum is extremely limited. All the exhibits can be viewed in 20 minutes or less and are for the science-minded individual. We went to this free museum, the free Polish-American (one room) museum in the area and another historical spot near Carpenter's Hall that was also free. If you have already seen the major and secondary Philadelphia historical attractions, this is an inexpensive alternative.
ReviewTitle: Small museum but you can enter for free

ReviewText: OK, in the interest of full disclosure, I would, most likely, qualify as a nerd. At least my daughters would assert so. I grew up in the 50s. and yes one of my favorite Christmas presents was a chemistry set which grew into a "chemistry corner" in the garage. There my buddies and I made rocket fuel and other noxious substances. Sputnik came along and suddenly kids who could do some science got a lot of encouragement. Went to college as a biochemistry major, ended up a double major in history and biology, and landed in medicine. My wife's background is also in science: first marine science and then health care. We could have spent half a day in this museum but even those without a science background will find enough here to be entertained for an hour or two, and smile or laugh more than once in the process. The museum is in the historic district and a short walk down Chestnut from Independence Hall. There is no admission fee, but you are asked to answer a few questions on a computer so the Foundation will have an idea what kinds of people walk through their door. The museum has two parts: a permanent collection featuring historical experimental equipment and video instructional material and a rotating exhibit which was featuring alchemy when we visited. The museum is airy and modern on the interior with staff that can help you find an exhibit that will appeal to your interests. For example, interested in fashion: there are exhibits dealing with the chemistry and development of dyes and synthetic fibers and cloth. Interested in health: how about one of the first NMR (MRI) machines. Too small to get inside and feel claustrophobic, they used small beach clams as subjects, and complete with the typewriter written note taped on the front (This machine is prone to fail at critical moments, do not panic). How about some complex three dimensional models of life-critical proteins complete with the story of how the gummy bears failed to hold the tooth picks representing bonds together in the initial model. Do all chemist enjoy a little well-contained explosion? You bet. Check out the giant video screen of the periodic table and press on sodium for a video of the "sodium party" where a remote control (read string stretched to shore) releases a piece of sodium into a bucket of water on a raft in a lake, to dramatic pyrotechnic effect. While you're there check out a few elements you've never heard off. It's a strange and fascinating world we live in. If your background is science, this little gem of a museum is well worth a detour. If not, and even if you found chemistry boring, the history, the genius and the serendipity of how our modern world emerged, and the profiles and humor of the individuals who made it happen will charm anyone with a bit of an open mind.

Thanks partly to the low-profile entrance and partly to the subject matter, this museum is especially easy to miss. Admission was free. Few tourists have chemistry in mind when they come to Philly (I certainly didn't), but that does not make this museum any less interesting. There's a small but spectacular collection of all things related to the history of chemistry. A perfect place to take shelter from the elements for an hour or so, especially if you're traveling with eggheads.

If you are interested in chemistry, you should visit this museum. Seeing primitive version of the laboratory equipments was fun for me. There was a big period table and it was fun to watch it. I enjoyed looking at the equipments which was used to save and ruin (which supposedly save but they didn't know the consequences) some peoples life. It is a free museum where you can learn something.

Bearing in mind I nearly failed High School chemistry, the Chemical Heritage Foundation is a good museum. It's small, free, (although a donation is requested) and full of interesting exhibits on chemistry, and how it has been interpreted over the years, as well as the role it plays in everyday life.

Even those who are not into the actual nuts and bolts of chemistry, this attraction shows the traveler how we have come a long way from it's infancy, trial and errors and items we use today. On display are antiquated machines that started the uses of equipment from medical to alchemy. You are greeted by a knowledgeable person who will give you a brief description what you are about to view on display. They do ask not to touch the machines. You can take photos but no flash. Admission is FREE. They do, however, have a donation box where you can deposit the funds. An update new interior with a few seats dot the interior and air-conditioned. Within walking distance to other attractions.

I spent roughly 1.5 hours walking the museum on my last visit, and being the fan of both history and science that I was, I was curious to see what this experience would hold for me. People, this is truly a hidden gem. Located just a few blocks north of the Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell, if you plan to play tourist in this town make this a part of your trip. You will be blown away at how clean, neat, and beautiful the museum is, and how easy it is to get lost reading up on all of the amazing advances made over the years, right down to the origin of sciences like alchemy. Best recommendation, bring a book and kick back for some peace and quiet. I wish this was available for me back in my college days, it is SO peaceful in there. Cheers!

We visited Woodmere to see the special exhibition of John Mosley photography which was fascinating. Through his great photos we learned a lot about Philadelphia and the Philadelphia African American community the 1940's to 1960's. We also viewed another fascinating exhibit showing "The Night Before Christmas " through various paintings a.nd other art forms. While these are temporary exhibits, it certainly demonstrates Woodmere's creativity. We look forward to visiting them again for future exhibits.

It was so wonderful to see so many local artists of all ages. All the artists were either from Philadelphia or trained in the area. The building itself was wonderful and we also went on a Sunday which had free admission. This museum combined with taking a walk on Germantown Ave in Chestnut hill made a very pleasant day.
ReviewTitle: Wonderful stop during a nice ride in the country part of the city

ReviewText: Woodmere Art Museum is a wonderful museum that tells the story of Philly's artists and their art. Currently Biblical Art is displayed in honor of the Pope's visit to Philadelphia. Also on exhibit are works by Raymond Theel, who painted impressionistic landscapes of Jarretown, PA, his hometown. They really support children and have a room where their art is displayed too. Art classes are offered for adults and children. There are movie and Jazz nights. We used a museum pass, so it was free. There are Sunday docent tours on the first Sunday of every month at 1:30 p.m. that are free too. If you want a little culture, seek out Woodmere Art Museum!

My wife and I visited this lovely museum today just outside Chestnut Hill and were impressed with the exhibits and fine service. It is small enough to be personal and large enough to be worthy of a visit! There is plenty of on site parking, free admission on Sunday's, Jazz on Fridays and a well stocked gift shop. Visit them now and enjoy the experience! Highly Recommended!

Sundays are free at Woodmere, located about 20 minutes from center city on the fringes of Fairmount Park. Currently on display are many works by women and some fine Hudson River School pieces. The museum began in a home with wonderful architectural features and stained glass, and a clean contemporary rotunda was added. This is not one of those huge overwhelming museums in which one can reach the saturation point and should become a member for frequent visits. Just take your time and enjoy this visual feast. A gift shop full of interesting picks lets you take your visit home.
ReviewTitle: Lovely afternoon in a gilded age mansion

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: We enjoyed pausing for a bit, and being able to eat at the Museum, instead of having to leave & come back.... so this restaurant / cafe was a great "find", that we did not expect. We just shared a sandwich, and it was kinda "pricey", but good and fresh. They had salads, soups, and I believe Salmon also, but the sandwich looked best. If drink and dessert prices had been lower, we would have made more food purchases. However, we loved the cafe setting -- very open and well-lighted, and of course the Art!
ReviewTitle: Cafe Inside of the Museum of Art

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: But like in all other, the prices are higher than the quality. Wish they would have a larger variety of healthy foods (I'm a vegetarian striving to eat vegan whenever possible).

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: There's a good choice of soups and a large salad bar from which to make your own lunchtime selection. Prices are reasonable. Seating is in a light and airy room. A good place to stop and rest: you'll need to if you want to see all that the Museum has to offer.

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: Lots of good choices - salad and soup bars, and sandwich, burrito and chicken stations. There were also pre-made sandwiches. We shared black bean soup, an outstanding chicken burrito and a wickedly rich brownie. Nice selection of beverages. The desserts are located by the cashiers, so it's really difficult to pass up adding a cookie or brownie to your meal!

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: Fabulous place for brunch before or after visiting the museum. For $35 per person, the brunch buffet is extensive and delicious. Options included prime rib, eggs made to order, shrimp and grits, eggs Benedict , brioche French toast (yummy) plus salad bar. A dessert buffet follows the meal plus coffee and a drink from the bar of bloody mary( custom made for you), mimosa, prosecco or champagne. So worth the cost. Wonderful wait staff. Everyone was charming.

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: I always stop by this place everytime I'm in Philadelphia, great food and great people. Nice environment as well. Thank you....

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: Good restaurant with rafinated food and excellent service, great possibility to have a break in visiting this splendid museum. Squash soup tasted splendidly, salmon was a bit too greasy, but generally the quality of food is high there, even if that place is a bit pricey.

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: Great for a relaxing afternoon after viewing some of the "treasures" of the Museum. Nice to just sit and rest your feet and contemplate on the beautiful works of Art that you are viewing

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: Servce was great! Food was awesome! This was a treat after being in the museum the entire morning. I will return...however, this time I think I will check out the chef's table. Yummy!

ProviderLocation: 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia , PA 19130-2302 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy , Philadelphia, PA 19130-2302
ReviewText: The food preparation and presentation is excellent. The atmosphere is relaxing and the staff is top notch. It is not inexpensive for lunch, but it well worth the price to visit such a charming museum restaurant.

A very pleasant surprise to find this small but very interesting museum, it certainly brought back childhood memories of the famous Wells Fargo Stagecoaches. This should encourage other historical corporations to open up their heritage to the general public!
If only more corporations set up this kind of tribute to their history and contribution to the nation's past, I think we'd have more of an understanding of how things unfold over time.

This museum is good for all ages. The video presentation was interesting and informative, and there are excellent activities, like printing an old $5 bill with your own face on it. Admission is free, as are the activities. The staff is friendly and helpful. Don't miss the actual stagecoach in the bank lobby next door. I wish more large corporations would follow Wells Fargo's example and set up museums like this.

We came across this museum by accident while staying in a nearby hotel and loved it. There was cool stuff to look at, there were things you could do - interaction type things like having your photo taken while sitting in/on a stagecoach or learning how to drive one by using the actual leather reins. There was no cost, they have a small souvenir section and we highly recommend it to adults and children! Thanks Wells Fargo.

If you have an hour to kill nice place to visit. Interesting exhibits on early banking. They give you some great insight as to how banking was conducted in early 1800's Best of all it's free Worth a stop

This small, quiet museum at the corner of S. Broad and Walnut, was right around the corner from my hotel, so it was convenient to stop in for a few minutes. There was interesting banking history, old money, and several interactive activities for the kids. I don't know if it's worth going too far out of your way, but it is only a couple of blocks south of City Hall.

It took me awhile to make it inside the museum after passing it by many times. I assumed it would be a small, brief history of Wells Fargo due to the size, but was very surprised by the variety of interactives, media and artifacts. It is a wonderful, cultural gem right on South Broad. I would recommend any one stopping in when they have a moment!
ReviewTitle: A nice surprise on Broad St.

ReviewText: Not what I was expecting but nevertheless very worthwhile. Great gift shop with delightful staff. I thought i would see more about textiles in general: the history and development as well future of textiles. Feels more like an art gallery. We did not see any general textile exhibits but did see an interesting show curated by Ann Hamilton. who included objects from Philadelphia University as well as the Philadelphia Museum of Art and Winterthur. A docent took us on a tour with about ten other people. It took about 45 minutes.
ReviewTitle: Unique, interesting space with focussed exhibitions.

ReviewText: Saw a write up of the place in a visitors magazine so we thought we'd stop in on our way to the Reading Terminal Market (.Make sure you go there, though.) Stopped in and should have stepped right out. Not worth the time or trouble. Really nothing to see. Noisy, dark, hot and empty (mostly). It's not a museum of "Fabric". I don't know what it's a museum of. It has nothing to do with fabrics. Don't bother.

But don't bring your mom. The contemporary art here is free to see, the tours are free and the guides answer questions well. Fabric, sound, video, and dinosaur-fossils were all media used in the exhibits on the day I visited. I liked the screen-printing exhibit the best.
ReviewTitle: Great for designers and artsy types

ReviewText: After having lunch yesterday at Reading Terminal Market, we finally made it to the Fabric Workshop and Museum. On Sunday it appears that admission is free or whatever one wants to donate. I asked where we paid, and I was directed to the donations jar and told there was no charge. The shop does have many interesting and unique gift items. No artists were there working on a Sunday. My husband asked, apparently one can make an appointment to see an artist at work during the week. The problem is that a docent must accompany you into the galleries. I could understand if they had historic fabrics or the like, but we are talking two galleries filled with photography encased in glass. Exactly what is the risk? Then we were going to have to wait to go to the second floor until other people finished looking at the photographs (which were interesting black and white views of Philadelphia, BTW) due to the low staff number and again, the requirement that all visitors be accompanied.. We decided we really didn't care to wait and left for PAFA to see the watercolor show in the historic building instead.
ReviewTitle: Not What We Thought It Would Be

ReviewText: We had taken a walk from our hotel (the Sonesta) to the Reading Market via Arch Street. It was early (just before 8AM) and we saw one of a few windows of the wares they had for sale. It was those windows that made us stop by when their shop was open. In particular for one of the items they showed - The Eroded Camera. I knew after seeing it, we had to go back when the shop was open. In the end I wish we had the time and strength to stay and visit the museum.....
ReviewTitle: Wishing we had taken the time to visit more than their shop...

ReviewText: I love textiles and textile products and had looked forward to this museum. The current exhibit was a bit peculiar - there are performances being held occasionally and the performance spaces are the focus of the exhibit. I want to go back when there is a more typical exhibit to see what that would be like. The gift shop is wonderful to explore as well - lots of creative works!

The only reason I am giving this an "Average" is because only one of the three galleries was open when I stopped, and to get there an associate had to take me to the other "storefront" and stand there while I looked at things. Not an ideal situation. But unlike some small museums I have visited recently, at least the lights were on. And it was open on a Monday which was a a plus. Actually the best part of the visit was the museum store. Its very well stocked with interesting, and not too expensive items- and not ones you would find in many places.
ReviewTitle: Gift shop is worth the stop

ReviewText: We popped in here on New Years Eve so that i could show my girlfriend some of the elaborate costumes and help her understand what the mummers tradition is all about. We are both outa-towners but ive been to the parade many times before. Ron showed us around and personally spent about an hour explaining all the costumes, different clubs, the whole tradition, we got to try some costumes on and practice our strut. Many thanks Ron. Go Vikings !
ReviewTitle: A very interesting and Informative Tour

ReviewText: This is a great way to learn a little bit about the history of one of Philadelphia most unique traditions -- Mummers. Lots of customs and props on display, and you can't beat free.
ReviewTitle: You Won't Find Something Like This Anywhere Else

ReviewText: You can make it through this free museum in a half hour. It is really only one large room, but has some nice Polish things for sale and has some interesting displays. Nothing amazing but nice for free.

I did not know this museum existed, but was pleasantly surprised when I found it. My partner and I are not Polish, but we wanted to stop by and explore the museum. The woman who greeted us, taught us more about the exhibits, and invited/told us about the celebration for Poland's independence was EXTREMELY nice and helpful. I really liked her and I'm so grateful she was present. The museum has free admission, but we gave a small donation. It is a large room filled with many different paintings, artifacts, and stories. I really enjoyed it and learned a lot. It was a really nice stop in and I felt so welcomed. The history was so interesting to learn about.
This is a very small museum which features exhibits on Polish history and culture including a display of "Great Men and Women of Poland.

This is a great little museum and gift shop dedicated to Polish culture. It is a wonderful tribute and comprehensive history of the Polish history. It highlights many important landmarks in Polish history and and makes you proud to be embrace your heritage! Even if you (sadly) have no Polish blood to claim, come visit anyway and learn the history of this amazing resilient people and their contributions to the world.

Very quaint museum, filled with Polish history. Even having no Polish ancestory, I was amazed at the artifacts and subject matter that the Polish know all too well. Very impressive display of their culture. Leaders past and present. Also a space with a large bust of Pope John Paul II. I had a chance to speak with Caroline at the gift shop area. Very pleasant to talk to and can answer any question about the museum and Polish heritage. Plenty of pamphlets as you walk in and feel welcomed. It is free and short walking distance to see other attractions. Recommended. Worth the time.

This museum is small, free, air conditioned (many surrounding sights are not), and has items from a variety of influential Polish people, including Copernicus, Curie, St. John Paul II, Pulaski, etc. Other pieces show life in Poland and Poland in World War II.

Nice to be able to see a bit of my Polish heritage in between visits to historic sites and local bites (of Philly Cheese steaks, pretzels and Italian Ice!) Very close to Independence Hall and Liberty Bell. Went with my mother quite a few years ago.

While visiting Philadelphia we were looking for something to do and we stumbled on the Simeone Automotive Museum. We weren't sure what to expect, but when we arrived we were pleasantly surprised by the number and quality of the cars. Furthermore, they have a philosophy of preserving the cars and not restoring them, so they are in their best untouched condition. They have a great collection of race cars from the early 1900's through the 1950s and some very rare cars. Furthermore, they have demo days once a month where they actually drive some of the cars. Check them out, because you won't be disappointed!
ReviewTitle: What a great collection of cars! A must see for any car enthusiast...

ReviewText: We spent a week in Philadelphia. On day 5, we decided to venture out of downtown Philly. While researching for things to do close by, we stumbled upon the Simeone Car Museum. My husband is a car buff and worked in the racing division of large automotive company. He loves old cars. The museum blew us away. Seeing so many old racing cars, in original condition, in one place was quite an experience. I am not a car person but I truly enjoyed seeing these beautiful cars! Plan to spend more than an hour. More people visiting Philly should know about this car museum. Or if you have a several hour layover at the airport, it is an easy cab ride to the museum.

I had heard about this museum for awhile, and since they had a special exhibit on Subaru there, I popped in to see it. While this museum is focused on racing, there is plenty to see and experience. A veterinary conference was going on the day I was there, that took up the main hall (museums can not live on admission ticket sales alone.) I would be interested to see how they use that space when they are not hosting something. Lots to see, a NASCAR hall, and a number of vignettes that portray specific era vehicles. I was never able to get the app to work while I was there, finally did so when I got home. So I would suggest downloading it prior to going. (Though they had free wifi, it was too busy (probably with the conference) to fully download while I was touring.
ReviewTitle: Fun Museum for folks who like automobiles

ReviewText: The museum is larger than it looks, and even has a guided tour that can be downloaded in the apple or google app stores. We are new to the Philly area and we were looking for something fun to do when my parents came to visit. Dad loves cars and has made his career as a mechanic. The week that we visited, the museum was featuring 50 years of the mustang.

I have been to several car museums, and this one is tops in the pre-1950s cars. They also excel in race cars, not just classic cars. I saw on MotorWeek that they routinely take the cars out and run them around the lot and the public is welcome.
